plan_check_fees: FIRE DEPARTMENT COMMERCIAL PLAN REVIEW FEE: Sprinkled Building $348.00. Non-sprinkled Building $205.00. Addition $253.00. Remodel - under $58,001.00: Fees range from $45.00 (for $1.00 to $1,000.00) to $250.00 (for $57,001.00 to $58,000.00). Remodeling over $58,000.00: $253.00.
permit_issuance_fees: New Construction and Additions: Based on Cost per Square Foot (CSF) times Total Square Footage (TSF) times Local Variable Factor (LVF) of $0.00098. CSF determined by International Code Council Building Valuation Table. Minimum Fee - $40.00. Remodeling, Alterations, and Repairs over $500.00, fence installations, inground pool Installation, communication towers, and utilities: Fees range from $40.00 (for estimated construction costs $1.00 to $3,000.00) to $320.00 (for estimated construction costs $99,001.00 to $100,000.00). *PLUS $0.90 per thousand dollars of estimated construction cost thereafter, up to $1,000,000.00 total estimated construction cost. *PLUS $0.60 per one thousand dollars of estimated construction cost thereafter (above $1,000,000).
inspection_fees: South Bend inspection fees for development include a reinspection fee of $40.00, and an additional final inspection fee of $60.00 if a previous final inspection failed. For stand-alone residential or commercial new construction in the Northeast Neighborhood Development Area, there is a design review fee of $160.00.
expedited_review_fees: South Bend charges an 'expediting fee' for special events on public property when an applicant misses the filing deadline and requests expedited review by City departments. This fee is an additional charge to offset the cost of the expedited internal review process.
resubmittal_fees: The City of South Bend does not charge additional fees for resubmittals of development plans.
temporary_certificate_fees: The 2025 Fee Schedule for the St. Joseph County/City of South Bend Building Department lists the following temporary certificate fees: Temporary Signs: Initial Permit $40.00, Each Extension $45.00; Tent and Temporary Structures: First Term: $40.00, Renewal: $45.00; Temporary Electrical Services (All amperage): $7.00. There is no explicit fee listed for a 'Temporary Certificate of Occupancy' in the provided fee schedule.
demolition_permit_fees: In South Bend, the demolition permit fee for residential properties is $0.02 per square foot, with a minimum fee of $40.00. If work is performed without a required permit, the fees will be tripled as a penalty.
water_capacity_fees: South Bend implements water capacity fees, also known as system development charges, for new connections to the municipal water works. According to various city documents, these fees have been $475.00 for a new water connection, and more recently, $500 for a water connection as of a 2017 ordinance and a 2025 developer's guide. Additionally, a sewer connection fee of $1,145 is also mentioned.
sewer_capacity_fees: For new connections to the South Bend Municipal Sewer Works, a system development charge of $1,145.00 is collected. For county residents requiring a sewer tap, there is a $50 fee for a Utility Verification Form plus a $1,030.50 system development charge.
water_transmission_fees: The South Bend Water Works Schedule of Rates & Minimums for 2025 details various water-related fees. While the specific term 'water transmission fees' is not explicitly used, the document outlines 'WATER/SPRINKLER RATE' based on consumption (per ccf) and 'WATER & SPRINKLER MINIMUM' charges, which vary by meter size and whether the service is inside or outside the city limits. Outside rates are 14% higher than inside rates. Additionally, a 'Water Ins' charge of $2.10 is applied. The document provides rates effective January 2024 for water and sewer, and effective January 1, 2025, for storm water user fees and solid waste rates.
sewer_transmission_fees: South Bend developed a system development charge (SDC) to recover costs for water and sewer infrastructure. The city proposed an SDC of $500 per equivalent residential unit (ERU) or equivalent dwelling unit (EDU) for new connections. However, the Indiana Office of Utility Consumer Counselor (OUCC) recommended an approval of $465 per ERU based on their cost calculations.
transportation_fees: The South Shore Line, serving South Bend, is planning a approximately 10 percent fare hike. This fare increase is attributed to inflationary pressures and is also related to the funding requirements for a $112 million project to reroute the South Shore Line to the South Bend Airport. The Northern Indiana Commuter Transportation District (NICTD) is seeking additional funding from the Indiana General Assembly for this project.
parks_recreation_fees: The South Bend Venues Parks & Arts (VPA) develops recreation fees with the objective of generating revenue, as recognized by the Parks Board in their department services pricing policy. Fees for programs, activities, and events are established following the approval of the executive director for the Board of Park Commissioners. For park facilities use, the City of South Bend has standard field reservation fees. Specific rental fees for parks are categorized as follows: Community Use at $100, Private Use at $500, and Commercial Use at $1,000 for single-day events up to 8 hours. Scholarships for discounted rates are available on a first-come/first-served basis for events that align with VPA’s impact drivers, typically capped at a 50% discount.
public_safety_fees: The South Bend Common Council approved an ordinance on August 11, 2025, to raise fees for public access to police body camera and dashboard camera videos. The new fees, effective January 1, 2026, will charge members of the public $25 per hour, up to $75 per video. This is a reduction from the initially proposed $150 maximum per video. Previously, individuals only paid for the cost of the disks, which was less than $20.
fire_protection_fees: The City of South Bend's Fire Department Commercial Plan Review Fees for development in 2025 are as follows: Sprinkled Building: $348.00; Non-sprinkled Building: $205.00; Addition: $253.00. Remodel (under $58,001): Fees are tiered based on estimated construction cost, ranging from $45.00 (for $1-$1,000) to $250.00 (for $57,001-$58,000). Remodeling (over $58,000): $253.00.
library_fees: The St. Joe County Public Library in South Bend eliminated late fees for overdue materials and rental fees for DVDs starting January 1, 2022. However, the library introduced an annual fee for guest access cards for non-residents. This fee was initially $50 per year starting in June 2022, and later increased to $90 for a non-resident guest card.
school_impact_fees: N/A - Based on the conducted searches, there is no direct evidence to confirm that South Bend, Indiana, currently levies school impact fees for development. While general information about impact fees exists, and the City of South Bend has a 'Site Development Guide' that mentions site plan review fees, no specific information regarding school impact fees was found.
general_government_fees: The City of South Bend, through the St. Joseph County/South Bend Building Department, has a 2025 permit fee schedule for development. Fees for new construction and additions are calculated based on Cost per Square Foot (CSF) times the Total Square Footage (TSF) times a Local Variable Factor (LVF) of $0.00098. CSF is determined by the International Code Council Building Valuation Table. There is a minimum fee of $40.00 for new construction and additions. Remodeling, alterations, and repairs over $500.00 have a tiered fee structure starting at $40.00 for estimated costs up to $3,000.00, increasing incrementally. For costs exceeding $100,000, there's a base fee of $320.00, plus $0.90 per thousand dollars up to $1,000,000, and $0.60 per thousand dollars thereafter. The Fire Department Commercial Plan Review also has fees for sprinkled ($348.00) and non-sprinkled ($205.00) buildings, additions ($253.00), and remodeling (tiered fees). Northeast Neighborhood Development Area Design Review has a fee of $160.00 for stand-alone residential or commercial new construction. Electrical permit fees are also detailed, with a minimum fee of $40.00.
storm_drainage_fees: South Bend introduced a new monthly stormwater fee on January 15, 2019, which went into effect on June 1 of the same year. The fee was set at $2 per month for residential properties and $5 per month for non-residential properties. This initiative was projected to generate approximately $1 million annually to fund upgrades and improvements to the city's stormwater system. Prior to this, South Bend was noted as the only city in Indiana with a population over 25,000 without such a fee.
water_meter_fees: South Bend's water meter fees are part of a comprehensive rate adjustment plan for the years 2022-2025. This plan was approved by the Indiana Utility Regulatory Commission, with the last rate increase occurring on January 25th, 2023. The purpose of this multi-year adjustment is to gradually increase rates to meet the operational and capital needs of the city's utilities, based on recommendations from a commissioned long-term rate plan.
sewer_connection_fees: For county residents in South Bend, connecting to the municipal sewer system involves a Utility Verification Form fee of $50, a system development charge of $1,030.50, and a sewer tap permit request fee of $25.
water_service_line_fees: South Bend assesses a monthly charge of $2.10 per water user, which is deposited into the Water Service Fund. This fund is exclusively utilized for the repair and/or replacement of leaking water service lines. These rates became effective on July 1, 2022.
fire_service_connection_fees: For development in South Bend, the fees related to fire service include: Fire Department Commercial Plan Review Fees: Sprinkled Building: $348.00; Non-sprinkled Building: $205.00; Addition: $253.00; Remodel: Fees vary based on estimated construction cost, ranging from $45.00 (for $1.00 to $1,000.00) up to $250.00 (for $57,001.00 to $58,000.00), and $253.00 for remodels over $58,000.00. Fire Protection Sprinkler System: Up to 30 heads: $40.00; Each additional 10 heads thereafter: $8.00. System Development Charges (SDCs) are generally applicable for new municipal utility accounts and are due prior to connecting to City water and sewer. While the Site Development Guide states the City Connection Fee is the SDC, a specific 'fire service connection fee' as a separate SDC was not detailed in the provided fee schedule.
reclaimed_water_fees: N/A - No specific information regarding "South Bend reclaimed water fees development" was found in the search results. Information on general water and stormwater utility fees for South Bend, Indiana, was identified, but not for a dedicated reclaimed water fee development program.
utility_relocation_fees: The City of South Bend imposes System Development Charges (SDCs) for new construction that connects to the city's municipal water and sewer systems. These charges are a component of development costs related to utility infrastructure. While general "utility relocation fees" for development were not explicitly detailed, the SDCs serve a similar function in offsetting infrastructure costs. The St. Joseph County Code of Ordinances mentions "Reset, relocation and reconnect fees" of $40 each, but their applicability to large-scale utility relocation for development could not be confirmed due to technical issues accessing the full document.
grading_permit_fees: N/A - The South Bend Building Department's 2025 permit fee schedule does not list specific 'grading permit fees'. Development projects involving grading would likely fall under the general building permit fees. For new construction and additions, fees are calculated as: Cost per Square Foot (CSF) × Total Square Footage (TSF) × Local Variable Factor (LVF) of $0.00098, with a minimum fee of $40.00. For remodeling, alterations, and repairs over $500, the fees are based on estimated construction costs, ranging from $40.00 (for costs up to $3,000) to $320.00 (for costs up to $100,000), with additional charges for higher estimated costs.
drainage_fees_site: For site development in South Bend, Indiana, drainage-related fees are included within the plumbing permit fee schedule. This includes a fee of $6.00 for 'drain within building for rainwater systems' and $12.00 for 'drywells.' Additionally, new construction dwellings require a sewer and/or water permit from the South Bend Engineering Department. The general building permit fees for new construction and additions are based on the cost per square foot, total square footage, and a local variable factor, with a minimum fee of $40.00.
private_street_fees: N/A - There is no explicit information regarding 'private street fees development' in South Bend based on the provided search results and the reviewed South Bend Fee Schedule.
landscaping_review_fees: The Northeast Neighborhood Development Area Design Review Fee for all stand-alone residential or commercial new construction in South Bend is $160.00. This fee is in addition to and separate from any other permit, processing, or review fees.
irrigation_permit_fees: The permit fee for a lawn sprinkler system in South Bend, including backflow protection devices, is $6.00 per meter.
fence_permit_fees: The fence permit fees in South Bend are based on the estimated construction cost (labor and materials). For projects with an estimated construction cost between $1.00 and $3,000.00, the permit fee is $40.00. The fee increases incrementally with higher construction costs, up to $320.00 for projects valued at $99,001.00 to $100,000.00. For projects over $100,000.00, the fee is $320.00 plus an additional $0.90 per thousand dollars of estimated construction cost thereafter, up to $1,000,000.00 total estimated construction cost, and $0.60 per thousand dollars thereafter. There is also a penalty for performing work without a required permit, in which case the permit fees shall be tripled.
zoning_review_fees: South Bend zoning review fees for development include: Design Review Fee (Northeast Neighborhood Development Area Overlay District): $160 for stand-alone residential or commercial new construction. Subdivision Fees: Major Primary: $1000; Major Secondary: $1200 + recording fee; Minor Subdivision: $625 + recording fee; Administrative Lot Line Adjustment: $375 + recording fee; Plat Vacation: $250 + recording fee; Re-recording: $250 + recording fee. Rezoning (Zone Map Amendment) Fees: Single Family Use: $300; Other than Single Family Use: $675. Variances and Special Exceptions Fees: Development Variance – Single Family Use: $125; Development Variance – All Other Uses: $300; Special Exception: $300; Use Variance: $300; Additional variances, or variances included with other development approvals: $50. Other Fees: Improvement Location Permit – Limited (signs, interior remodel, change in use): $50; Improvement Location Permit – Site Plan: $100.
conditional_use_fees: The conditional use fee for development in South Bend, Indiana is $300.00.
variance_fees: South Bend has variance fees for development. A Development Variance for Single Family Use costs $125.00, while a Development Variance for uses other than Single Family costs $300.00.
rezoning_fees: South Bend rezoning fees are $200.00 for Single Family Use and $500.00 for Other than Single Family Use.
planned_development_fees: The planned development fees for South Bend are as follows: Planned Unit Development (PUD) Rezoning Filing Fee: $150.00; PUD Secondary Approval (Site Plans Filing Fee): $150.00; PUD Minor Modification (Site Plans Filing Fee): $50.00.
design_review_fees: NORTHEAST NEIGHBORHOOD DEVELOPMENT AREADESIGNREVIEW FEES: All stand-alone residential or commercial new construction, in addition to and separate from any other permit, processing, or review fee: $160.00.
historic_review_fees: The Northeast Neighborhood Development Area Design Review Fees in South Bend are $160.00 for all stand-alone residential or commercial new construction, in addition to and separate from any other permit, processing, or review fee.
environmental_review_fees: N/A - Specific environmental review fees for development in South Bend were not found in the publicly available 2025 Permit Fee Schedule or other related development ordinances. The fee schedule outlines fees for building permits, fire department commercial plan reviews, and various other permits related to construction and development, but no distinct 'environmental review fee' category was identified.
tree_removal_fees: There is no fee for tree removal permits in South Bend, Indiana.
wetlands_review_fees: The City of South Bend has the following development review fees that are likely applicable to projects involving wetlands: ESCP Review: $100.00; ESCP/Site Development Permit - Per acre of disturbed land (max $1000): $100.00 (partial acres round up); Drainage Review: $150.00. These fees are part of the Engineering Review Fee Schedule for Subdivisions, Rezoning, Site Plans, and Miscellaneous Land Use.
air_quality_fees: N/A - I could not find information specifically detailing "South Bend air quality fees development." However, search results indicate that South Bend is involved in various air quality initiatives, including the implementation of low-cost air quality sensors, participation in a Climate Action Plan for 2024 with strategies for air quality and heat relief programs, and an approved revision to the South Bend/Elkhart 1997 8-hour ozone maintenance state air quality implementation plan.
noise_study_fees: N/A - There is no information available regarding noise study fees for development in South Bend, Indiana, based on the executed searches and analysis of relevant city ordinances. The city's code of ordinances outlines regulations for unreasonable noise and associated penalties, but does not specify any fees for noise studies.
traffic_study_fees: N/A - The City of South Bend's 'SMALL SCALE DEVELOPER HANDBOOK' indicates System Development Charges for water ($500) and sewer ($1245) connections per residential unit, which are waived for buildings with 5 residential units or less and non-profit development corporations. The 'Engineering Review Fee Schedule' includes Site Development fees: ESCP Review ($100.00), ESCP/Site Development Permit ($100.00 per acre of disturbed land, max $1000), Drainage Review ($150.00), and Utility Verification Form ($50.00). Specific traffic study fees or traffic impact fees were not explicitly listed in the accessible documents.
archaeological_fees: N/A - The Programmatic Agreement for HUD-Funded Programs in the City of South Bend, which outlines the process for addressing archaeological resources in development projects, does not specify any archaeological fees or development fees.
biological_survey_fees: N/A - I could not find specific information regarding biological survey fees for development in South Bend, Indiana.
right_of_way_fees: South Bend's right-of-way fees include occupancy fees (e.g., $75/day/lane for arterial/collector streets for complete closure, $35/week for local streets for non-traffic restrictions) and excavation fees ($200/cut for street excavation, $25/cut outside curb/treelawn). Development-related fees include an Engineering Review Fee Schedule for subdivisions (e.g., Major-Primary $200, Minor $125), rezoning (e.g., $75 for other than single family, $150 for Planned Unit Development), and site plans (e.g., Final Site Plans $50). There are also ESCP (Erosion and Sediment Control Plan) review fees ($100) and per-acre fees ($100/acre, max $1000).
street_cut_fees: South Bend's street cut fees include an excavation fee of $200 per cut for street excavation (100' or less) and $25 per cut for outside curb/treelawn excavation (100' or less). An additional $25 is charged for each 100' of excavation. Development fees listed include an ESCP Review fee of $100, an ESCP/Site Development Permit fee of $100 per acre of disturbed land (max $1000), a Drainage Review fee of $150, and a Utility Verification Form fee of $50. Occupancy fees for right-of-way vary by street type (Arterial, Collector, Local) and restriction type (Complete Closure, Traffic Lane Restrictions, Non-Traffic Restrictions). For Arterial and Collector streets, complete closure and traffic lane restrictions are $75/day/lane and $50/day/lane respectively, with non-traffic restrictions at $35/week. For Local streets, complete closure is $75/week, traffic lane restrictions are $35/week, and non-traffic restrictions are $20/week. Construction fees include: Replacement-in-kind for Curb or Sidewalk is $0, Residential Driveway Approach is $40, and Non-residential Driveway Approach is $120. New construction for Curb or Sidewalk is $5/10 linear feet ($25 minimum), Residential Driveway Approach is $60, Non-residential Driveway Approach is $155, and Roadway or Alley is $10/10 linear feet ($50 minimum).
traffic_signal_fees: N/A - There is no readily available information detailing specific 'traffic signal fees' for development in South Bend, Indiana. While the City of South Bend has general permitting and engineering review fees, and engages in professional service agreements for traffic signal engineering, a distinct fee specifically for traffic signal development was not found in the reviewed documents.
street_lighting_fees: South Bend's street lighting development includes a Lamppost Lighting Program that offers discounted solar-powered lampposts to homeowners. Homeowners in designated target areas pay $50, while those outside these areas pay $250. Additionally, the city, in partnership with Indiana Michigan Power, is upgrading 9,000 streetlights to LEDs, a project aimed at reducing electricity consumption and saving costs.
sidewalk_fees: South Bend has a Curb & Sidewalk Reimbursement Program to assist property owners with repair costs. Homeowners can be reimbursed $20 per linear foot for sidewalks, and $15 per linear foot for curbs. In designated target areas, reimbursement rates increase to $40 per linear foot for sidewalks and $30 per linear foot for curbs. Additionally, there is a reimbursement of $950 for all ADA accessibility ramps.
driveway_approach_fees: South Bend driveway approach fees are as follows: Replacement-in-kind: Residential Driveway Approach: $15; Non-residential Driveway Approach: $40. New Construction: Residential Driveway Approach: $60; Non-residential Driveway Approach: $155. Additionally, there are Engineering Review Fees related to development, including fees for subdivisions, rezoning, and site plans.
oversized_load_fees: The city of South Bend implemented new fees for oversized, overweight, and hazardous material loads, as part of a new ordinance approved on November 22, 2021. The updated fees include $35 for a single-use permit for oversized, overweight, and hazardous loads, and $50 for a one-time annual permit.
sign_permit_fees: South Bend sign permit fees for development, as of the 2025 Fee Schedule, are as follows: Under one (1) square foot or less: No fee; 1 to 25 square feet: $40.00; 26 to 50 square feet: $60.00; 51 to 100 square feet: $85.00; Over 100 square feet: $120.00; Temporary Signs: Initial Permit $40.00, Each Extension $45.00.
electrical_permit_fees: Electrical permits issued and obtained prior to commencement of the work for which such permit is required, the following fees shall be levied, with a minimum permit fee being $40.00. Temporary Services (All amperage): $7.00. Switchboards and Panel Boards each (new and replaced): 60 amp $7.00, 100 amp $9.00, 200 amp $12.00, 400 amp $15.00, 600 amp $20.00, Over 600 to 2,000 amp $25.00, Over 2,000 amp $50.00. Circuits, each (new or replaced): $5.00. Horsepower (machinery): First hp $7.00, Each additional hp $0.25. Back-up generator: $10 Kw or less $40.00, Over 10 Kw $50.00. Pool wiring and/or bonding $40.00. Repair, extension, and/or maintenance of wiring $40.00. Reset, Relocation, and Reconnect, each $40.00.
plumbing_permit_fees: In South Bend, plumbing permit fees for development and new construction are itemized based on specific work categories. There is a minimum plumbing permit fee of $40.00. Individual fees apply to various components such as: each plumbing fixture or trap ($6.00), backflow protection ($6.00), building sewer (under 100' for $12.00, 100' or over for $25.00), building water (under 100' for $12.00, 100' or over for $25.00), water softener ($7.00), trailer park sewer ($10.00), drain within building for rainwater systems ($6.00), water heater and/or vent ($7.00), gas reconnection ($40.00), each gas piping system per outlet ($3.00), industrial waste pretreatment interception ($8.00), installation/alteration/repair of water piping and/or water treating equipment ($6.00), repair or alteration of drainage or vent piping ($6.00), drywells ($12.00), and lawn sprinkler systems on any one meter ($6.00). Fire protection sprinkler systems cost $40.00 for up to 30 heads, plus $8.00 for each additional 10 heads. Gas tanks and pumps cost $12.00. Back-up generator gas lines are $40.00 for 10 Kw or less and $50.00 for over 10 Kw. Reinspection fees are $40.00, and additional final inspections are $60.00.
mechanical_permit_fees: The mechanical permit fees for South Bend, as per the 2025 Permit Fee Schedule, include a minimum permit fee of $40.00 for heating and air conditioning permits. Specific fees are levied based on the type and capacity of the installation: Space heaters (30,000 BTU input or more): $40.00 each; Warm-air furnaces, unit heaters, cabinet heaters, radiant tube heaters: $40.00; Oil and gas conversions: $40.00; Electric furnaces (air handling): $40.00; Air Conditioning (Central, electric): Less than 10 tons: $40.00; Over 10 tons: $60.00; Water Chillers: $85.00; EMI air blowers: $40.00; Ventilating and exhaust systems, unit ventilators: Less than 500 CFM: $6.00; 500 to 1,500 CFM: $12.00; $1.00 for each 500 CFM or fraction thereof in excess of 1,500 CFM; Ventilating Commercial Hoods: 500 CFM to 1,500 CFM: $60.00; Over 1,500 CFM: $120.00; Refrigeration and Engine-drive, gas-fired, or oil-fired cooling equipment: 1 to 5 horsepower: $17.00 each; 6 to 10 horsepower: $40.00 each; More than 10 horsepower: $45.00 each; Rooftop combination furnace and air conditioning units (60,000 BTU to 3,000,000 BTU's): Up to 7.5 tons: $45.00; 7.5 tons or more: $70.00; Heat pumps: 1,000 to 60,000 BTU's input: $40.00; 60,000 to 300,000 BTU's input (Up to 7.5 tons): $45.00 each; 7.5 tons or more: $85.00 each; Earth, coupled water source: $60.00; Boilers, steam or hot water: Up to 300,000 BTU: $40.00; 300,000 BTU or more: $60.00; Through-wall combination air conditioning/heating, VAV boxes with coil: First unit: $40.00; Each additional unit: $12.00; Solar heat units: $60.00; Air handlers: 400 CFM to 2,500 CFM: $40.00; Over 2,500 CFM: $70.00; Back-up generators - gas line: 10 Kw or less: $40.00; Over 10 Kw: $50.00; Duct and register: First 15 openings, per system: $40.00; Each opening thereafter, per system: $1.00; Gas Reconnection: $40.00 each; Gas Piping (distribution of piping to equipment): $3.00 per outlet; Wood burning stoves, per flue (including chimney and chimney connector): $40.00; Each reinspection fee: $40.00; Each additional final inspection: $60.00.
fire_sprinkler_fees: FIRE DEPARTMENT COMMERCIAL PLAN REVIEW FEE: Sprinkled Building $348.00. Non-sprinkled Building $205.00.
elevator_permit_fees: The Indiana Department of Homeland Security sets the following fees for regulated lifting devices, which include elevators: Installation or Alteration Permit: $500; Initial or Renewal Operating Certificate: $120. These fees are established under 675 IAC 12-3-14.
tenant_improvement_fees: In South Bend, tenant improvement fees fall under the category of 'Remodeling, Alterations, and Repairs over $500.00'. The permit fees are based on the estimated construction cost: $1.00 to $3,000.00: $40.00; $3,001.00 to $4,000.00: $45.00; $4,001.00 to $5,000.00: $50.00; ... (fees increase incrementally based on estimated cost); $99,001.00 to $100,000.00: $320.00; For estimated construction costs over $100,000, the fee is $320.00 plus an additional $0.90 per thousand dollars up to $1,000,000.00, and $0.60 per thousand dollars thereafter. There are also separate fees for electrical permits, fire department commercial plan review (if applicable), and re-inspection fees.
subdivision_fees: South Bend subdivision fees include: Major Primary Subdivision: $800.00; Major Secondary Subdivision: $800.00; Minor Subdivision: $500.00; Replat (includes combining primary & secondary): $300.00; Planned Unit Development: $1,000.00; South Bend City Clerk fee: $100 or $150 if Annexation is included; South Bend Engineer fee: $75.
platting_fees: South Bend, Indiana platting and development fees include: Major Secondary Subdivision: $800.00; Minor Subdivision: $500.00; Administrative Lot Line Adjustment: $300.00; Plat Vacation: $250.00; Re-recording: $250.00; South Bend City Clerk fee: $100 or $150 if Annexation is included.
annexation_fees: South Bend's annexation fees can range from $100 to $150 if annexation is included in a project. For development, upfront residential fees are capped at $5,000, while commercial fees could exceed $100,000. Additionally, a system development charge of $1,145 is applied for new connections to the South Bend Municipal Sewer Works.
development_agreement_fees: N/A - The City of South Bend does not appear to have a single, explicitly detailed "development agreement fees" schedule readily available through general searches. However, related development fees and charges have been identified: Northeast Neighborhood Development Area Design Review Fees: All stand-alone residential or commercial new construction in this area are subject to a $160.00 design review fee, in addition to other permit and processing fees. System Development Charges (SDC): For every new connection to the South Bend Municipal Water Works, a system development charge of $475.00 is collected. These charges cover the cost of connecting new customers to the water and sewer infrastructure. Professional Fee for Development Agreements (Unverified): A search snippet from the St. Joseph County Redevelopment Commission minutes (May 12, 2022) indicated that "Once the Development Agreement is approved there is actually a. $250,000 professional fee and that would cover a lot of the work that is done...". However, attempts to access the full document to verify the nature and general applicability of this fee were unsuccessful due to website timeouts. Downtown Riverfront Development Administration Fee: For businesses outside of downtown but within the Municipal Development District, applicants must agree to pay a $1,000 annual administration fee for Riverfront Development.
public_improvement_fees: South Bend, Indiana, charges various development-related fees, as outlined in the St. Joseph County/City of South Bend Building Department Permit Fee Schedule for 2025. While a specific category titled "public improvement fees" is not explicitly listed, the following fees are directly related to development and public improvements: Building Permit Fees for New Construction and Additions: These fees are calculated based on the "Cost per Square Foot (CSF) times the Total Square Footage (TSF) times the Local Variable Factor (LVF) of $.00098." The minimum fee is $40.00. The Cost per Square Foot (CSF) is determined by the International Code Council Building Valuation Table in effect each January, with specific rates amended for various occupancy classifications. Remodeling, Alterations, and Repairs over $500.00, fence installations, inground pool installation, communication towers, and utilities: These fees are tiered based on the estimated construction costs, starting from $40.00 for costs between $1.00 and $3,000.00 and increasing incrementally. For costs of $100,000 and up, the fee is $320.00, plus $0.90 per thousand dollars up to $1,000,000.00 total estimated construction cost, and $0.60 per one thousand dollars of estimated construction cost thereafter. Northeast Neighborhood Development Area Design Review Fees: For all stand-alone residential or commercial new construction within this area, there is an additional and separate fee of $160.00. Fire Department Commercial Plan Review Fees: These fees apply to commercial projects and include: Sprinkled Building: $348.00; Non-sprinkled Building: $205.00; Addition: $253.00; Remodel: Fees vary based on estimated cost, from $45.00 for up to $1,000.00 to $250.00 for costs between $57,001.00 and $58,000.00. Remodeling over $58,000 is $253.00. Electrical Permit Fees: These fees apply to electrical work with a minimum permit fee of $40.00, and vary depending on the service (e.g., temporary services, switchboards, circuits, horsepower, back-up generators, pool wiring, repairs).
bond_processing_fees: South Bend does not have a single, standardized 'bond processing fee' for development. Instead, various bond-related costs and fees are associated with development projects: Development Area Bonds: An estimated fee between $60,000.00 and $70,000.00 was discussed for Development Area Bonds in the process of being worked through, as noted in the September 24, 2024 meeting minutes of St. Joseph County. This is an estimated fee, not a definitive processing fee. Performance Bonds: For development projects, a Performance Bond for 125% of the Estimated Construction Cost may be required. The premium for these bonds typically ranges from 1% to 3% of the total project value, depending on factors such as credit score, project size, and experience. Contractor Registration Bond: A five thousand dollar ($5,000.00) bond made payable to the City of South Bend is required for contractor registration. Bond Issuance Costs: The costs of selling and issuing bonds are often included in the bond proceeds. Northeast Neighborhood Development Area Design Review Fees: For stand-alone residential or commercial new construction in this area, there is a design review fee of $160.00, separate from any other permit, processing, or review fees. For specific details on bond forms and associated fees, the Engineering Department advises contacting the Permit Office at 574.235.9254.
application_fees: South Bend development application fees are as follows: Subdivision: Major Primary: $1000; Major Secondary: $1200 + recording fee; Minor Subdivision: $625 + recording fee; Administrative Lot Line Adjustment: $375 + recording fee; Plat Vacation: $250 + recording fee; Re-recording: $250 + recording fee. Rezoning (Zone Map Amendment): Single Family Use: $300; Other than Single Family Use: $675. Variances and Special Exceptions: Development Variance – Single Family Use: $125; Development Variance – All Other Uses: $300; Special Exception: $300; Use Variance: $300; Additional variances, or variances included with other development approvals: $50. Other Fees: Re-advertisement of tabled petition: $75; Improvement Location Permit – Limited (signs, interior remodel, change in use): $50; Improvement Location Permit – Site Plan: $100; Written Commitments: $100 + recording fee; Zoning Verification Letter – Limited: $50; Zoning Verification Letter – Detailed: $100; Administrative Appeal to the BZA: $500.
hearing_fees: N/A - In South Bend, hearing tests are generally offered free of charge by providers such as AudioNova (formerly Darr Hearing) and Miracle-Ear. The cost of hearing aids in the area varies significantly, with traditional prescription hearing aids typically ranging from approximately $2,000 to $7,000 per pair. Over-the-counter hearing aids are available at a lower price point, generally between $200 and $1,400.
appeal_fees: South Bend appeal fees related to development are as follows: Development Variance – Single Family Use: $125; Development Variance – All Other Uses: $300; Special Exception: $300; Use Variance: $300; Additional variances, or variances included with other development approvals: $50; Administrative Appeal to the Board of Zoning Appeals (BZA): $500.
modification_fees: The fee for a PUD (Planned Unit Development) - Minor Modification in South Bend, Indiana, is $50.00.
extension_fees: The City of South Bend's 2025 Fee Schedule lists an 'Each Extension' fee of $45.00 for Temporary Signs. No specific 'extension fees' for general development, building permits, or zoning applications were found in the official fee schedule or related documents.
reinspection_fees: Each reinspection for commercial and industrial projects: $40.00. Each additional final inspection necessitated by the failure to pass previous final inspection: $60.00. Reinspection fee, each (Electrical): $40.00. Additional final inspection, each (Electrical): $60.00.
after_hours_fees: N/A - Information regarding 'after-hours fees development' in South Bend for permitting or development activities could not be definitively located. A City Council discussion in May 2025 mentioned a $100 added fee for building permit inspections, but the context did not specify if this fee applies to services rendered after regular business hours.
duplicate_permit_fees: The South Bend City Council has implemented an additional $100 fee for building permit inspections. This new fee is charged in addition to the existing building permit fee, meaning property owners will incur multiple costs for permits related to construction or renovations.
coastal_commission_fees: N/A - South Bend, Indiana is an inland city and does not have a coastal commission or associated fees for coastal development.
airport_overlay_fees: The City of South Bend has an 'Airport Economic Development Area' which is subject to design review, but no specific 'airport overlay fees' are required for development within this area. The only development overlay district that requires a design review fee ($160) is the Northeast Neighborhood Development Area Overlay District.
flood_zone_fees: N/A - South Bend, Indiana, does not appear to have explicitly named 'flood zone development fees' based on direct search queries. However, the city does impose a Municipal Separate Storm Sewer System (MS4) program fee, which is a flat rate of $2.25 per month for residential properties and $7 per month for non-residential properties, appearing as 'STORMWATER RES' on utility bills. Additionally, development in flood hazard areas requires a development permit, implying associated costs, although specific 'flood zone fees' were not identified.
seismic_review_fees: N/A - The City of South Bend's 2025 permit fee schedule, issued by the St. Joseph County/City of South Bend Building Department, does not contain any explicit mention of "seismic review fees" for development.
wildfire_prevention_fees: N/A - There is no information available regarding 'South Bend wildfire prevention fees development'. Searches for related terms such as 'fire prevention development fees' and 'environmental regulations development fees' in South Bend also did not reveal any specific fees associated with wildfire prevention development.
desert_conservation_fees: N/A - There is no information available regarding "desert conservation fees" in South Bend. However, South Bend does have various development fees. These include planning and zoning fees (e.g., Development Variance, Special Exception, Use Variance), system development charges for new connections to the municipal water and sewer works, and annual administration fees for riverfront development within the Municipal Development District.
school_district_fees_specific: The South Bend Community School Corporation's After School Program (Kaleidoscope) has a $25 enrollment fee per child and costs $60 per child per week, collected bi-weekly at $120 per child.
water_district_fees_specific: South Bend charges a 'Building Water' fee for development. For new construction, the fee is $12.00 if the water line is under 100 feet, and $25.00 if it is 100 feet or over.
fire_district_fees_specific: South Bend has specific Fire Department Commercial Plan Review Fees for development. For new construction, the fees are: Sprinkled Building: $348.00; Non-sprinkled Building: $205.00; Addition: $253.00. Remodeling fees vary based on estimated construction costs, starting at $45.00 for projects up to $1,000.00 and increasing incrementally.
improvement_district_fees: South Bend employs several mechanisms for funding public improvements and development, rather than a single category of "improvement district fees." These include: Building Permit Fees: Detailed in the St. Joseph County/City of South Bend Building Department Permit Fee Schedule for 2025, these cover new construction, additions, remodeling, and various electrical, plumbing, and HVAC permits. Northeast Neighborhood Development Area Design Review Fees: A specific fee of $160.00 is charged for stand-alone residential or commercial new construction within this designated area. System Development Charges (SDC): These are collected for new connections to the City's Municipal Water and Sewer Works, covering the cost of connecting new customers to these services. For instance, new water connections incur a $475.00 charge. Municipal Development District Administration Fees: Businesses located within the Municipal Development District are subject to a $1,000 annual administration fee. Special Assessments: While not fully detailed, special assessments are mentioned in relation to delinquent property taxes and conservancy districts, indicating their use in funding certain local improvements. Tax Increment Financing (TIF): This financial tool captures the increase in property tax revenue generated by new development within a specific area to fund public improvement projects in that same area. Redevelopment Districts/Commissions: These entities are responsible for approving and funding local public improvement projects within their designated areas.
assessment_district_fees: In South Bend, assessment district fees have been replaced by System Development Charges as of October 2016. These charges are imposed upon connection of new customers to the water or sewer utility and for new uses by existing customers that materially change demands on the utility. For wastewater, a system development charge of $1,145 is collected per Equivalent Residential Unit (ERU). An ERU is defined as a single-family residence or estimated wastewater flows of 310 gallons per day for other customers. Similar system development charges and lineal foot assessments for water main installation are also in place for both inside and outside city limits. Exemptions apply for new structures replacing a prior structure of similar use on the same property.

plan_check_fees: The development plan check fees for Evansville are part of the 'Building and construction fee schedule' outlined in the city's ordinances. These fees vary based on the type of construction (one- and two-family dwellings, multifamily dwellings, or other new construction and additions) and are calculated per square foot of gross floor area, with minimum fees also specified. For example, the general rate for one- and two-family dwellings and modular homes (including additions) is a minimum fee plus a rate per square foot of gross floor area. Detached garages/carports and residential or agricultural outbuildings over 100 square feet also have a per-square-foot fee with a minimum. Commercial and other occupancy types have different per-square-foot or per-cubic-foot rates.

Foundation permit (nonrefundable): Residential: $30.00; Commercial: $75.00.

Repair, remodel (no new circuits): Residential: $30.00; Commercial: $50.00. Temporary service: $30.00. Gas/electric activation: $30.00. Plumbing Permits and Inspection Fees: Fixtures and openings (each): $6.00. Sanitary sewer: $6.00. Water service: $6.00. Water heater: $6.00. Gas piping: $6.00. Orifice change (when installed with subsection (C)(1) of this section): $6.00. Water heater or fixture replacement: Residential: $25.00; Commercial: $50.00. Grease trap: $35.00. New gas meter: Residential: $30.00; Commercial: $50.00. Minimum fee (for subsections (C)(1) and (2) of this section): $30.00. HVAC Permit and Inspection Fees: New unit heat: $1.50 per 10,000 BTU. Residential: $30.00; Commercial: $60.00. Repairs -- Replacement. For repairs and replacements for units of same type and size in BTU and efficiency as original unit (b) For the installation or the replacement with a 12 SEER+ residential AC replacement unit: $12.50. expedited_review_fees: N/A - The Evansville | Vanderburgh County Area Plan Commission Services Fee Schedule (effective January 1, 2023) does not explicitly list any 'expedited review fees' for development. It includes fees for various permits, rezoning, variances, and subdivisions. A 'PLAT DEFICIENCY RE-REVIEW FEE' is noted for additional reviews beyond the initial two included with subdivision filing fees, but this is not categorized as an expedited review fee.
resubmittal_fees: The resubmittal fee for development in Evansville, specifically for 'Re-Inspection for Corrective Actions Ordered,' is $85.00 per inspection.
temporary_certificate_fees: N/A - As of the current information from Evansville's official building and construction fee schedules, there is a $30.00 fee for a 'Temporary service' electrical permit. Additionally, permit extensions cost $30.00 for residential and $100.00 for commercial projects. A specific, distinct fee explicitly labeled for a 'temporary certificate of occupancy' or a general 'temporary certificate' for development was not found in the reviewed documents.
water_capacity_fees: Evansville Water and Sewer Utility charges developers who install meters for the cost of the meter, inspection, and application processing. The developer-installed service charges are: $200 for a 3/4-inch meter, $230 for a 1-inch meter, and actual cost for meters larger than 1-inch (not less than the 1-inch meter charge). Monthly service charges and volume charges also apply, varying by meter size and water consumption.
sewer_capacity_fees: Evansville sewer capacity fees for development are determined by several factors, including monthly base charges, water-based consumption charges, and commercial tap-in fees. Base Charge: The monthly service charge varies depending on the meter size. Water-Based Consumption Charges: These charges are based on the quantity of water used, with different rates for commercial, industrial, and public authority customers. There are two components: a cost of service rate and an EPA consent decree rate. Commercial Tap-In Fees: For industrial, commercial, office, professional, warehouse, educational improvements, and other property types, the tap-in fee is calculated based on the size of the new water meter using specific equivalency factors. For example, a 5/8 inch meter has a factor of 1.0, while a 10-inch meter has a factor of 253.0. Specific multiplication factors apply to certain commercial property types, such as mobile homes (x 1), churches (x 1), and multi-unit residential properties (x 0.5 per unit if more than one unit).
water_transmission_fees: Evansville Water and Sewer Utility (EWSU) charges the following fees related to development: Developer-Installed Service Charge: 3/4-inch meter: $200; 1-inch meter: $230; Larger than 1-inch meter: Actual Cost*. Split Service Fee: $200 (for customers who water their lawns and want to avoid increased sewer charges, includes costs for the second meter, inspection, and application processing).
sewer_transmission_fees: The development of Evansville sewer transmission fees is primarily driven by the 'Renew Evansville' plan, a 25-year initiative by the Evansville Water and Sewer Utility. These fees are set annually by the Evansville City Council to fund significant sewer system improvements, including dramatic upgrades to existing infrastructure, construction of new infrastructure, and compliance with the Clean Water Act of 1972.
transportation_fees: The METS Micro on-demand public transit pilot service in Evansville charges a ride fee of $2.
parks_recreation_fees: Evansville parks and recreation fees include: Park and Recreation Service Fees (Examples): Picnic shelter rental: Resident $35.00, Nonresident $65.00, Profit organization $100.00; Swimming Pool Seasonal Pass: Resident $50.00, Senior Citizen Resident (65+) $75.00, Non Resident $85.00; Swimming Lessons (1st lesson per household): Resident $50.00, Non Resident $65.00; Recreational Baseball (T-Ball): Resident $20.00, Nonresident $25.00. Development Fees (Fee in lieu of dedication of parkland): 2020: Single-family (per lot) $1,219.66, Multi-family (per dwelling unit) $914.75; 2021: Single-family (per lot) $1,280.64, Multi-family (per dwelling unit) $960.45.
public_safety_fees: In Evansville, public safety is supported by various funding mechanisms and fees. These include revenue from a Public Safety Local Income Tax Fund. Additionally, specific fees contribute to public safety, such as annual permit fees for alarm businesses ($240 initial application, $120 annual permit), and administrative fees associated with public safety board decisions. Building permits also play a role in ensuring compliance with state and local safety and fire prevention codes.
fire_protection_fees: Evansville has fire protection connection fees that are based on the size of the connection, with annual charges ranging from $3.74 for a 1-inch connection to $1,833.18 for a 12-inch connection. There are also connection charges for connecting to the waterworks system, and a 'DEVELOPER-INSTALLED SERVICE CHARGE' for developers who install their own meters.
library_fees: The Evansville Vanderburgh Public Library (EVPL) has made a significant development in its fee structure by adopting a 'fine free' policy for overdue materials. This means that patrons are no longer charged daily fines for late returns. However, other fees remain in place, including: PLAC Card: $70.00; Nonresident Card: $90.00; EVPL Replacement Card: $1.00 (the first replacement card is free); Returned Check/NSF Check: $15.00; Lost/Damaged Materials Processing Fee: $6.00; Collection Agency Referral Charge: $10.00. The PLAC card fee is set by the Indiana State Library and is subject to change. The EVPL implemented its fine-free policy as part of a broader trend among Indiana public library systems to reduce barriers to access.
school_impact_fees: N/A - Based on the conducted searches, there is no clear evidence to confirm that Evansville, Indiana, has specific 'school impact fees' associated with development. The results included information on general impact fees and economic development bonds for a medical school project in Evansville, Indiana, but no explicit mention of school impact fees for broader development.

Work Done Without a Permit Administrative Fee: Residential: Quadruple Fees or 5% of total building permit cost; Commercial Buildings (<10,000 sq ft): 10% of total building permit cost; Commercial Buildings (>10,000 sq ft): 20% of total building permit cost. Other Development-Related Fees: Swimming pool permit: $15.00; Moving building permit: $17.50.
storm_drainage_fees: N/A - Explicit 'storm drainage fees for development' were not found for Evansville, Indiana. Development-related costs are likely encompassed within general building and construction permit fees, and water and sewer utility connection fees. Compliance with stormwater runoff control and management regulations is required for development projects, which may incur associated costs but not a distinct 'storm drainage development fee'. A filing fee for the Drainage Board may also apply, as indicated in a search snippet.
water_meter_fees: Developers in Evansville who install their own water meters are charged for the cost of the meter, inspection of the installation, and application processing. The fees are as follows: 3/4-inch meter: $200; 1-inch meter: $230; Larger than 1-inch meter: Actual Cost (not less than the charge for a 1-inch meter).
water_service_line_fees: Evansville has several fees related to water service line development. These include: Connection Charge: Covers the costs of excavating and tapping the main, installing service pipe from the main to the lot line, installing the saddle and stop box, and furnishing the meter. Fees are $1,635 for a 3/4-inch meter and $2,080 for a 1-inch meter, with larger meters charged at actual cost. Split Service Fee: A charge of $200 for customers who apply for split services to avoid increased sewer charges for lawn watering. This fee covers the second meter, inspection, and application processing. Water Tap Front-Footage Fee: A charge of $26 per foot (up to 300 ft.) when new water service is initiated, covering the installation cost of the water main that supplies water to the address. Developer-Installed Service Charge: Developers who install their own meters are charged for the cost of the meter, inspection of the installation, and application processing.
fire_service_connection_fees: Evansville has a 'Developer-Installed Service Charge' for meters installed by developers. The charge is $200 for a 3/4-inch meter, $230 for a 1-inch meter, and actual cost for meters larger than 1-inch. There are also 'Private Fire Connection Surcharges' based on meter size, which are annual fees.
reclaimed_water_fees: N/A - No specific information regarding 'Evansville reclaimed water fees development' was found. While Evansville has a Water and Sewer Utility with published sewer rates and ongoing wastewater system improvements (Renew Evansville project), there is no explicit mention of a fee structure for reclaimed water or its development in the search results or official utility websites reviewed.
utility_relocation_fees: N/A - Information regarding 'Evansville utility relocation fees development' could not be specifically located. General fees for water and sewer services, connections, and developer-installed services are available through the Evansville Water & Sewer Utility. One source indicated that utility relocation may be 100% reimbursable under certain conditions.
grading_permit_fees: N/A - The City of Evansville, Indiana, does not have a separate, explicit fee for a 'grading permit.' Instead, grading requirements are integrated into the overall building permit process for development. A site grading plan is required under specific conditions when applying for a building permit (e.g., if the lot is within 75 feet of a 'regulated drain,' in a 100-year floodplain, or near a natural drain/watercourse). The fees for building permits, which would encompass development involving grading, are outlined in Section 15.05.470 of the City's municipal code and are typically calculated based on the gross square footage of the construction.
drainage_fees_site: N/A - For site development in Evansville, Indiana, there are no direct fees for permits related to drainage work within the city's right-of-way. However, detailed drawings showing the location and type of work, materials used, and drainage calculations must be provided with the application for approval by the Board of Public Works.
private_street_fees: N/A - The Evansville Vanderburgh County Area Plan Commission's fee schedule, effective January 1, 2023, includes the following fees related to subdivision development, which would encompass private street development: Major Subdivisions (including Replats): Filing Fee: $500.00 + $10.00 per lot; Plat Release: $250.00 + $10.00 per lot. Minor Subdivisions (including Replats): Filing Fee: $250.00 + $25.00 per lot; Plat Release: $125.00 + $25.00 per lot. Subdivision Waiver: $300.00 + $50.00 per additional request; Sidewalk Waivers/Alternative Plan (requiring public meeting): $100.00. There are no explicitly listed "private street fees"; instead, these costs are integrated into the overall subdivision filing and plat release fees.
landscaping_review_fees: Based on the 'APPENDIX A FEE SCHEDULE' from Evansville, Wisconsin: Site plan review fee: $300, plus reimbursement of municipal consulting costs for site plan review. Community Development Landscape Review (Minimum): $1,000.00.
irrigation_permit_fees: The Evansville Water & Sewer Utility has the following fees related to irrigation permits and development: Split Service Fee: $200. This fee applies to customers who desire a second meter for watering their lawns to avoid increased sewer charges. It covers the cost of the second meter, installation inspection, and application processing. Developer-Installed Service Charge: This charge applies to developers who install meters themselves and covers the cost of the meter, installation inspection, and application processing. The fees are: 3/4-inch meter: $200; 1-inch meter: $230; Larger than 1-inch meter: Actual cost (not less than the 1-inch meter charge).
fence_permit_fees: Retaining walls and fences: < 6 ft. $30.00; > 6 ft. $30.00 + $5.00 per ft.
zoning_review_fees: Evansville, IN Zoning Review Fees for Development (Effective January 1, 2023): Improvement Location Permits: Commercial Site Review Application: $125.00 (No fee for Small Cell Facilities (SCF) requiring site review); Multi-Family/Commercial/Industrial Permits (New Structure/Addition/Change of Use): $200.00 + $0.05 per building sq. ft. tree_removal_fees: Tree removal services in Evansville, Indiana, generally range from $495 to $673. For trees on private property in Evansville, a permit is typically not required for removal. However, the removal of public trees necessitates a permit from the Tree Advisory Board. A recent ordinance update (G-2022-25) amended sections related to the composition and appointment of the Tree Advisory Board, but did not specify new tree removal fees or procedural developments beyond the existing public tree permit requirement. No explicit fees for tree removal permits within Evansville, IN, were identified.
wetlands_review_fees: N/A - The City of Evansville, Wisconsin, does not explicitly list a 'wetlands review fee' in its Appendix A Fee Schedule. air_quality_fees: The City of Evansville's air quality fees are established and regulated under Chapter 16.05 of its Environmental Code, which was updated by Ordinance G-2024-2, passed on February 28, 2024. This code includes provisions for general fees, construction/installation fees for new facilities or equipment, and annual operating fees. The Evansville Climate Collaborative (ECC) is responsible for implementing programs related to air quality and compliance with these regulations. Details on the specific development process of these fees, such as public hearings or detailed justifications for the fee amounts, are not explicitly available in the reviewed public documents.
noise_study_fees: N/A - The City of Evansville, Wisconsin's Municipal Code and Fee Schedule do not explicitly list any fees for 'noise study fees development' or similar charges for conducting noise studies.
traffic_study_fees: The Evansville/Vanderburgh County Area Plan Commission charges a Commercial Site Review Application fee of $125.00 for development projects. This fee is required for most uses other than single-family, duplex, agricultural, and certain small cell facilities, and would cover the review process which may include a traffic impact study as part of a larger development application.
archaeological_fees: Evansville, Indiana, does not appear to have a single, consolidated "archaeological development fee." However, development projects may incur various archaeological costs and fees: 1. Application Fee for Historic Preservation: The Evansville Historic Preservation Commission charges a $25.00 application fee for a Certificate of Appropriateness for exterior changes to properties within historic preservation areas or districts. These projects may involve archaeological considerations. 2. State-Level Archaeological Data and Review Fees: The Indiana Department of Natural Resources (DNR), Division of Historic Preservation and Archaeology (DHPA), charges fees for archaeological professionals to access its online database (SHAARD) and GIS map: An annual fee of $1,000 for the first user at a firm or university, and $500 for each additional account. For those not subscribing annually, project area maps can be pulled by DHPA staff for a fee of $70.00 per hour. 3. Project-Specific Archaeological Work Costs: Development projects in Indiana, particularly those requiring federal permits or funding, or disturbing ground near cemeteries, may incur significant costs for archaeological surveys, excavations, and mitigation. An example from Perry County, Indiana, cited a $200,000 bill for archaeological work on an industrial park development.
biological_survey_fees: N/A - Specific biological survey fees for development in Evansville were not found in the search results. However, a general biological assessment cost estimate sheet from the Navajo Nation Department of Fish and Wildlife indicates that such surveys typically involve an hourly rate of $80/hour for research, planning, travel, review of findings, and report writing. Additional overhead costs include mapping, per diem (estimated at $50/night), mileage ($0.30/mile), and a daily vehicle rate ($15/day), along with a 10% administration fee.
right_of_way_fees: N/A - The City of Evansville, Indiana, does not have a single, distinct 'right-of-way fee.' Instead, development within the city's right-of-way requires various permits, and the associated costs are based on the type of construction or work being performed. These include, but are not limited to, fees outlined in the 'Building and construction fee schedule': Building Permits and Inspection Fees: One- and two-family dwellings and modular homes (including additions): $0.06 per square foot of gross floor area (minimum $100). Detached garages/carports and residential/agricultural outbuildings over 100 sq ft: $0.06 per square foot (minimum $100). Other new construction and additions (commercial, industrial, etc.): Rates vary by occupancy type, e.g., $0.08 per gross square foot for 'A' occupancies, $0.06 for 'B' occupancies. Minimum fees apply. Retaining walls and fences: $30 for < 6 ft, $30 + $5.00 per foot for > 6 ft. Electrical Permits and Inspection Fees: Services: $30 for < 400 amps, $30 + $12.50 per each 100 amps over 400 amps. Per circuit, per building: $1.50 for 100 amps, $4.00 for > 100 amps. Plumbing Permits and Inspection Fees: Fixtures and openings (each), sanitary sewer, water service, water heater, gas piping, orifice change: $6.00 each. Minimum fee: $30.00. HVAC Permit and Inspection Fees: New unit heat: $1.50 per 10,000 BTU (minimum $30 residential, $60 commercial). Air Conditioning Permit and Inspection Fees: New unit (1-60,000 BTU): $45.00. New unit (60,001+ BTU): $8.00 per 12,000 BTU. The cost for large-scale right-of-way acquisition for major projects can be substantial, as evidenced by a 2025 Road Hearing document mentioning approximately $960,000 in right-of-way costs for a specific road project.
street_cut_fees: The street cut permit fee in Evansville, Indiana is $5.00. A street cut permit, issued by the Board of Public Works after review by the City Engineer's Office, is required before any person cuts into the surface of a street or sidewalk. The fee is payable to the City Controller.
traffic_signal_fees: N/A - Specific traffic signal development fees for Evansville, Indiana, are not explicitly detailed in the publicly available "Building and construction fee schedule" (document 15.05.470) from the City of Evansville. street_lighting_fees: In Evansville, Wisconsin, developers are responsible for the installation of street lighting within new subdivisions. The 'LAND DIVIDER’S AGREEMENT' for the Capstone Ridge Subdivision, for example, specifies that 'Public Improvements,' which include 'street lights,' shall be constructed, installed, furnished, and provided by the Developer.
sidewalk_fees: The City of Evansville has a "Barrett Law Sidewalk Replacement Program" which outlines the development of sidewalk fees. For petitions submitted before January 1, 2006, the cost-sharing was 25% property owner and 75% city. For petitions submitted after January 1, 2006, the cost-sharing is 50% property owner and 50% city. Property owners can participate by submitting a "Sidewalk Repair/Replacement Petition Form."
driveway_approach_fees: The City of Evansville, Wisconsin, has a fee of $55.00 for Driveway & Driveway Access. This fee was effective as of January 9, 2024.
oversized_load_fees: N/A - Evansville, Indiana, specifically Vanderburgh County, does not currently have an ordinance that regulates wide loads on county roads, and thus no specific oversized load fees are required for such routes.
