Site Plan Review (Non-Residential or Multiple Family Dwelling): Temporary Construction Trailer with Water/Sewer: $500; Outdoor Eating/Drinking/Smoking Areas or Gas Station Canopies: $200; Projects less than 1,000 sq ft: $250; Projects 1,000 - 10,000 sq ft: $500; Projects over 10,000 sq ft: $1,000. Certificate of Use: $50. Floodplain Development Permit: $100 - $200 (depending on zoning and whether part of another permit process). Development Plan (Primary or Secondary, Master Sign Plan): $1,000. Rezoning Requests: $1,000. Major Plat: $1,000. Minor Plat: $500. Downtown Pre-Review (New Construction/Addition, Major Facade Renovation): $350. Development Standards Variance: $350 - $500 (depending on zoning district).
expedited_review_fees: N/A - The Allen County and Fort Wayne Department of Planning Services Fee Schedule, effective March 1, 2025, does not explicitly list 'expedited review fees' for development. The schedule details various fees for permits, plan commissions, variances, and other administrative services related to development, but a separate fee for an expedited review process is not present.
resubmittal_fees: N/A - The Allen County and Fort Wayne Department of Planning Services Fee Schedule, effective March 1, 2025, does not explicitly list a general 'resubmittal fee' for development projects. However, it does include the following fees for amendments and modifications that may be associated with resubmittals: Written Commitment Amendment: $500; Amendment to Restrictive Covenants: $100; Correction of Scrivener's Error: $100; Renewal or modification of conditions of Hearing Officer or Board of Zoning Appeals approvals: $350 or $400.
temporary_certificate_fees: As of March 1, 2025, the fees for temporary certificates in Fort Wayne are: Temporary Construction Trailer with No Water or Sewer Facilities: No Fee; Temporary Construction Trailer with Water or Sewer Facilities: $500; Temporary Tent Permit: $50.
demolition_permit_fees: The demolition permit fees in Fort Wayne (as per the 2016 Fee Schedule) are: Commercial ground floor: Up to and including 4000 sq. ft.: $60.00; Over 4000 and including 10,000 sq. ft.: $100.00; Over 10,000 sq. ft.: The document was truncated, but the fees for demolition start at $60.00 for commercial ground floor demolitions up to 4000 sq. ft.
water_capacity_fees: Fort Wayne has a system development charge (water capacity fee) of $590 per equivalent meter for its municipal water utility. These funds are intended to finance the development of growth-related or capacity-related water facilities and are to be kept in a separate, interest-bearing account. The methodology used for calculating this charge, the equity buy-in method, was accepted by the Indiana Office of Utility Consumer Counselor (OUCC).
sewer_capacity_fees: Fort Wayne City Utilities utilizes "Monthly Capital Improvement Surcharges," also known as capital charges, to fund sewer capacity development. These charges reimburse City Utilities and/or developers for capital improvements made to areas in anticipation of future customers. The principle is that "growth pays for growth," meaning the cost of improvements is primarily paid by the future benefitting customers once they connect. The amounts and end dates for these charges are determined by estimating infrastructure costs and forecasting the number of customers who will benefit, with projected lengths of time for different areas (e.g., Rothman - 18 years, Upper Ely - 30 years) based on the connection date to the system.
water_transmission_fees: Fort Wayne utilizes "Monthly Capital Improvement Surcharges" (also referred to as capital charges) to fund water transmission fees development. These surcharges are used to reimburse Fort Wayne City Utilities and/or developers for capital improvements made in anticipation of future customers, particularly in areas requiring extended infrastructure. The cost of these improvements is primarily paid by future benefitting customers once they connect.
sewer_transmission_fees: N/A - The Fort Wayne Code of Ordinances, Chapter 51, outlines the framework for sewer transmission fees, specifically defining 'Area Connection Fees' and 'Capital Improvement Surcharges' related to development. Area Connection Fees are one-time charges per Equivalent Residential Unit (ERU) for connections within designated areas to cover costs of utility installations or improvements. Capital Improvement Surcharges are additional monthly charges collected from retail sanitary sewer users within designated capital improvement surcharge areas. However, the provided ordinance does not include the specific dollar amounts or a detailed schedule for these fees. These specific rates would likely be found in separate rate schedules or appendices published by Fort Wayne City Utilities.
transportation_fees: Fort Wayne has seen two key developments regarding transportation fees. The Community Transportation Network (CTN) is increasing its rates on August 1, 2025, citing increased operating costs. Additionally, Citilink raised its regular bus fares from $1.25 to $1.50, effective April 1, 2025, as part of efforts to address a financial deficit.
parks_recreation_fees: Fort Wayne's parks and recreation fees related to development are outlined in Chapter 158: Subdivision Recreation Space. Developers have the option to donate land for public park development, establish private recreational facilities, or make 'in lieu of payments' to the Fort Wayne Parks and Recreation Department. These cash payments are exclusively used for the acquisition and/or development of park and recreational facilities within the appropriate subarea. The payment amount is calculated based on the average land value per acre of the land that would have been dedicated, using the pre-development purchase price or appraisal, as determined by § 155.0450 of the Subdivision Control Ordinance, with a maximum of $200 per lot.
public_safety_fees: N/A - There is no readily available public information detailing the specific 'development' of general 'public safety fees' in Fort Wayne. However, the City of Fort Wayne does operate a 'Parking Meter Fund' which collects revenues from parking violations. These funds are disbursed by the Board of Public Safety and are used for purposes directly related to public safety and infrastructure, including the purchase and maintenance of parking meters, traffic signal devices, and the repair and maintenance of public streets. Recent public safety initiatives in Fort Wayne include increased downtown police patrols and various funding allocations for public safety departments and projects, as discussed by city officials.
fire_protection_fees: N/A - The Fort Wayne Fire Department does not list specific 'fire protection fees' for development in its Fire Prevention Code. Instead, it outlines various penalties for violations of the code. However, Fort Wayne City Utilities lists 'Public Fire Protection' rates. As of June 1, 2023, these rates vary based on the size of the water connection: 2 1/2″ is $57.86, 3″ is $83.31, 4″ is $148.09, and 6″ is $333.18.
library_fees: The Allen County Public Library in Fort Wayne removed overdue fines for most materials. However, fees are still in place for lost, damaged, or incomplete materials, as well as for services such as subscription cards, public library access cards (PLAC), Access Fort Wayne equipment overdue fines, non-sufficient funds checks, material recovery referrals, 3D printing, bags, earbuds, faxing, flash drives, parking, printing/copies, and various meeting room rentals and associated services.
school_impact_fees: N/A - There is no explicit mention of 'school impact fees' for development in Fort Wayne, Indiana, within the searched documents or the Allen County Department of Planning Services Fee Schedule. General development impact fees may exist, but specific 'school impact fees' were not found.
general_government_fees: The City of Fort Wayne's 2023 Operating Budget and 2024 Budget Book Publication list 'Economic Development Fees'. In 2023, these fees were reported as $7,500. The 2024 Budget Book Publication also lists 'Economic Development Fees' at $7,500.
storm_drainage_fees: Fort Wayne storm drainage fees are charged monthly to property owners. Residential properties are charged $5.90 per Equivalent Residential Unit (ERU) per month. Non-residential properties are charged $4.75 per ERU per month, based on the amount of impervious surface on their property (such as rooftop, sidewalk, driveway, and parking lot).
water_meter_fees: Fort Wayne City Utilities has various water meter fees and development charges. Water Usage Charge (effective June 1, 2023): Inside City (per 100 cu. ft.): First 2,500 cu. ft. at $2.69, next 9,500 cu. ft. at $2.51, and over 12,000 cu. ft. at $2.44. Outside City (per 100 cu. ft.): First 2,500 cu. ft. at $2.96, next 9,500 cu. ft. at $2.76, and over 12,000 cu. ft. at $2.68. Water Monthly Service Charge (effective June 1, 2023): Varies by meter size, ranging from $11.96 for 5/8″ and 3/4″ meters (Inside City) to $3,024.77 for 10″ and 12″ meters (Inside City). Fees for Damaged, Frozen, Lost, or Stolen Water Meter Replacement (effective June 1, 2019): Varies by meter size and components (meter only, radio only, radio & meter, pit meter only, pit meter & radio). For example, a 5/8″ meter only costs $134.18, and a 5/8″ X 3/4″ radio and meter costs $201.18. Exempt Water Radio and Meter Costs (effective December 12, 2022): The radio cost is $215.65 for all listed meter sizes. Meter costs vary by size, for instance, a 5/8″ x 3/4″ meter is $314.68, and a 10″ meter is $7,454.90. Hot water meters also have separate costs. System Development Charge (SDC): A one-time charge assessed for all permanent connections to the Fort Wayne water system to pay for system capacity and growth.
sewer_connection_fees: The Fort Wayne sewer connection fees, designated as Area Connection Fees, vary by area. As of January 1, 2024, the fees per ERU per month are: Central: $800.00; Northeast: $2,600.00; Northwest: $2,200.00; Southeast: $1,980.00; Southwest: $2,150.00. These charges are subject to change as warranted and authorized by ordinance.
water_service_line_fees: As of the document dated April 2024, the current water service connection fees in Fort Wayne for specific development areas are: Wheelock Road Corridor Area: $545.00 per water service connection. Till Road Area: $123.00 per water service connection. Thomas Road/Bass Road Area: $123.00 per water service connection. These fees are established in their respective special contracts or resolutions and are subject to annual adjustments.
fire_service_connection_fees: N/A - Fort Wayne fire service connection fees, including public and private fire protection charges, are established by Fort Wayne City Utilities with the approval of the Board of Public Works and City Council. These fees fund the operation, maintenance, repair, and replacement of the drinking water distribution system, and the cost of supplying water for fire fighting. While Fort Wayne City Utilities implements 'Monthly Capital Improvement Surcharges' for wastewater to reimburse for capital improvements in anticipation of future development (growth pays for growth), the search did not yield specific details on a comparable explicit development process for fire service connection fees tied to new development or capital charges beyond the general rate setting mechanism.
reclaimed_water_fees: N/A - There is no publicly available information regarding the development or current implementation of reclaimed water fees in Fort Wayne, based on searches of the Fort Wayne City Utilities website and broader web searches.
utility_relocation_fees: N/A - Fort Wayne's City Code of Ordinances details fees for right-of-way occupancy, excavation permits, and other development-related permits (e.g., commercial and residential access permits, sidewalk permits, poleline permits). However, explicit 'utility relocation fees' for development projects were not found in the accessible online sections of the code or related documents. The code refers to 'Rules and Regulations for Right-of-Way Occupancy and Barricade Permits' available at the City Clerk's office, which may contain this specific information.
grading_permit_fees: For Fort Wayne, the fee for 'Finished project grade changes in the floodplain and not qualifying for the Zoning Ordinance "Exceptions to Compensation Requirements", not part of another permit or process' is $300. Additionally, a 'Primary or Secondary Development Plan or Master Sign Plan' has a fee of $1,000.
drainage_fees_site: Fort Wayne drainage fees for site development, categorized under SWP3 submittal review and compliance inspections, are as follows: Single residential lot: $140 per hour for extra submittal review and $80 per hour for extra SWP3 inspection. Development (0-19.99 acres): $265 per hour for extra submittal review and $220 per hour for extra SWP3 inspection. Development (20+ acres): $355 per hour for extra submittal review and $220 per hour for extra SWP3 inspection. Note that review of initial submittals and a maximum of two resubmittals are performed at no charge. Hourly rates apply for reviews beyond this limit and for re-inspections following a Notice of Violation.
private_street_fees: Fort Wayne has a Public Rights-of-Way Rental Policy that outlines fees for individuals, companies, or organizations seeking to place private facilities within public rights-of-way, which would apply to private street development. The fees include: Initial Application Fee: $200; Contract Preparation Fee: $100; Annual Rental Fee: Varies based on the type of facility and street classification: Communication cable (excluding fiber optics): $0.54 per linear foot; Parking lots or other temporary structures: $0.54 per square foot; Underground pipe and duct: $0.81 per square foot (minimum 1 foot width); Fiber optics cable: $1.08 per linear foot; These base fees are multiplied by a factor of one for residential streets, two for collector streets, and three for arterial streets. Optional Notification Service Fee: An additional annual fee of $5,750 is applicable if the applicant does not join the Indiana Underground Plant Protection Service and desires city notification of nearby work.
landscaping_review_fees: For development in Fort Wayne, the filing fee for a Secondary Development Plan, which includes landscaping and screening plans, is $600. The filing fee for a Primary Development Plan, which also includes landscaping and screening plans, is $700. Architectural or general contractor fees for landscaping may be an exception at the decision of the Director of Community Development.
irrigation_permit_fees: N/A - Specific 'Fort Wayne irrigation permit fees development' were not found in the reviewed permit fee schedules and permit information pages for Fort Wayne. The available documents detail general development permit fees, but not a specific fee category for irrigation permits.
fence_permit_fees: The fence permit fee in Fort Wayne for all zoning districts and any type of fence is $30, effective March 1, 2025.
zoning_review_fees: The Fort Wayne zoning review and development fees, effective March 1, 2025, are as follows: PLAN COMMISSION FEES: Primary or Secondary Development Plan or Master Sign Plan: $1,000; Rezoning requests: $1,000; Downzoning an existing SFR use to R1 Zoning: $250; Primary or Secondary Major Plat - No Per Lot Fee: $1,000; Single Lot Primary or Secondary Plat Amendment: $250; Primary or Secondary Minor Plat: $500; Vacation Petition for Vacation (Plat, Right of Way, or Easement): $500. DOWNTOWN PRE-REVIEW FEES: Minor Facade Renovation: $50; Major Facade Renovation: $350; New Construction/Addition: $350. BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS FEES: Development Standards Variance (A1, A3, AR, R1, R2, R3, RP Districts): $350; Development Standards Variance (All Other Zoning Districts): $500; Use Variance - All Requests: $500; Special Use - All Requests: $500; Contingent Use - All Requests: $500; Appeal of Hearing Officer decision to the Board of Zoning Appeals: $350 - $400; Petition to appeal a Zoning Administrator determination, interpretation or decision: $400. ZONING VERIFICATION FEES: Zoning verification general (zoning only): $2; Zoning verification research (zoning, adjacent zoning, violations, overlay, BZA history): $100.
conditional_use_fees: In Fort Wayne, the fee for a Contingent Use (Conditional Use) request is $500. A Primary or Secondary Development Plan has a fee of $1,000.
variance_fees: DSV: Development Standards Variance: A1, A3, AR, R1, R2, R3, RP Districts (one fee - unlimited number of requests) $350; All Other Zoning Districts (one fee - unlimited number of requests) $500. UVAR: Use Variance - All Requests $500. SU: Special Use - All Requests $500. CU: Contingent Use - All Requests $500.

planned_development_fees: PDP: Development Plan Primary or Secondary Development Plan or Master Sign Plan $1,000
design_review_fees: Fort Wayne design review fees for development, effective March 1, 2025, are as follows: Site Plan Review (Non-Residential or Multiple Family Dwelling) Temporary Construction Trailer with No Water or Sewer Facilities: No Fee; Temporary Construction Trailer with Water or Sewer Facilities: $500; Outdoor Eating/Drinking/Smoking Areas or Gas Station Canopies: $200; Projects less than 1,000 square feet: $250; Projects of 1,000 square feet to 10,000 square feet: $500; Projects of over 10,000 square feet: $1,000. Downtown Pre-Review Minor Facade Renovation: $50; Major Facade Renovation: $350; New Construction/Addition: $350.
historic_review_fees: The Fort Wayne Department of Planning Services Fee Schedule, effective March 1, 2025, includes the following historic review fees related to development: Downtown Pre-Review (DTPR): Minor Facade Renovation: $50; Major Facade Renovation: $350; New Construction/Addition: $350.
environmental_review_fees: Fort Wayne environmental review and development-related fees include: Floodplain Development Permit Fees (Effective March 1, 2025): In an agricultural or residential zoning district (not part of another permit or process): $100; In commercial or industrial zoning district (not part of another permit or process): $200; In any zoning district (as part of another permit or process): $0; Zoning Ordinance "Exceptions to Compensation Requirements", not part of another permit or process: $100; Finished project grade changes in the floodplain (not qualifying for the Zoning Ordinance "Exceptions to Compensation Requirements," not part of another permit or process): $300. Development Plan Fees (Effective March 1, 2025): Primary or Secondary Development Plan or Master Sign Plan: $1,000. Miscellaneous Stormwater Charges (§ 53.63): Residential users: $25; All others: $100.
tree_removal_fees: N/A - A permit is required for tree removal in the public right-of-way in Fort Wayne. Specific tree removal permit fees for the City of Fort Wayne are not publicly listed online. The City of Fort Wayne's website advises to contact the Right-of-Way Office for permit fee structures.
wetlands_review_fees: N/A - Fort Wayne does not appear to have a separate, explicit 'wetlands review fee' for development. However, wetlands are a component of the overall development review process. A Primary or Secondary Development Plan, which requires the mapping of wetlands, incurs a fee of $1,000. Additionally, a Floodplain Development Permit is required, with fees ranging from $100 to $200, or $0 if integrated into another permit or process.
air_quality_fees: As of August 2025, there is no specific 'Fort Wayne air quality development fee' or a distinct local 'environmental impact fee' for developers solely related to air quality in Fort Wayne. However, any development in Fort Wayne that involves activities impacting air quality would be subject to air permitting and associated fees managed by the Indiana Department of Environmental Management (IDEM). These state-level fees vary based on the type of permit required (e.g., Title V, FESOP, MSOP, Registration) and the level of emissions. For example, annual fees for a Part 70 permit are $6,100 (base fee) plus $52.38 per ton for each regulated air pollutant emitted, with certain limitations. Additionally, application fees for new source permits can range from $793 for minor modifications to $9,525 for major PSD or emission offset permits. The Allen County Health Department also references an 'Air Pollution Control Ordinance' for Allen County, but specific development fees are not detailed on their public information page.
noise_study_fees: N/A - There is no explicit fee listed for 'noise study fees' or 'noise assessment' related to development in the Fort Wayne Department of Planning Services Fee Schedule (effective March 1, 2025). The fee schedule includes various permits and plan review fees, but not specific charges for noise studies.
traffic_study_fees: N/A - Fort Wayne and Allen County do not appear to have an explicit 'traffic study fee' for development. However, development projects are subject to 'Site Plan Review' fees through the Allen County and Fort Wayne Department of Planning Services. These fees vary based on the project size: Outdoor Eating/Drinking/Smoking Areas or Gas Station Canopies: $200; Projects less than 1,000 square feet: $250; Projects of 1,000 square feet to 10,000 square feet: $500; Projects of over 10,000 square feet: $1,000. These site plan review fees likely cover the administrative and engineering review of development plans, which would include assessing traffic impacts.
archaeological_fees: N/A - The City of Fort Wayne does not impose specific archaeological fees for development. While archaeological surveys may be required as part of development projects, these are costs incurred by the developer for services, not fees paid to the city for review. The Indiana Department of Natural Resources (DNR) charges an annual fee of $1,000 for the first user at a firm or university, and $500 for each additional account, for archaeological database and map access.
biological_survey_fees: N/A - Specific biological survey fees for development in Fort Wayne are not listed in the Allen County Department of Planning Services Fee Schedule (effective March 1, 2025). The fee schedule includes fees for various permits such as Improvement Location Permits, Site Plan Reviews, Floodplain Development Permits, and Zoning appeals, but no direct mention of biological survey fees or environmental review fees.
right_of_way_fees: Fort Wayne charges an initial application fee of $200 for the use of rights-of-way. Additionally, there is a $500 fee for a Petition for Vacation (Plat, Right of Way, or Easement), effective March 1, 2025.
street_cut_fees: The Fort Wayne Code of Ordinances, § 99.009, states that an initial application fee of $200 is required for the use of rights-of-way. This fee is to reimburse the city for administrative expenses necessary for the review and routing of the application.
traffic_signal_fees: N/A - The Fort Wayne Traffic Engineering Department is responsible for the design, installation, timing, and maintenance of traffic signals. Funding for traffic signal improvements primarily comes from Local Roads and Streets (LRS), CEDIT, federal, and private sources. Based on the reviewed fee schedules for Allen County and the City of Fort Wayne Department of Planning Services, there are no explicit 'traffic signal development fees' or 'traffic impact fees' directly levied on developers for traffic signal development. While there are fees associated with 'Development Plans' for primary or secondary developments, these are not specifically for traffic signals.
street_lighting_fees: N/A - Fort Wayne's street lighting development is primarily funded through the City's Community Development's local income tax infrastructure budget. Additionally, the City has cost-sharing improvement programs for street lighting. While some neighborhood associations may levy annual assessments that could contribute to street lighting, there is no direct evidence found of a city-developed, specific 'street lighting fee' for residents.
sidewalk_fees: Fort Wayne has a "50/50 Sidewalk Cost-Share Program" where the city and the homeowner each pay 50% of the sidewalk repair costs. The approximate cost for a homeowner is $275-$300 per sidewalk slab/square (usually 5'x5'). Some residents find these costs too high, with examples of homeowners being asked to pay around $3,000 for 10 sidewalk slabs.
driveway_approach_fees: The fees for driveway approach permits in Fort Wayne are as follows: Residential access permit, new construction: $40; Commercial access permit, new construction: $200; Commercial access permit, new construction with auxiliary lanes: $400; Commercial access permit, reconstruction: $100.
oversized_load_fees: The fee for an oversized/overweight load permit in Fort Wayne, Indiana, is $65.00, as per Fort Wayne Code of Ordinances 99.009. This fee applies to all permits except those for mobile homes.
sign_permit_fees: On-premise or Off-premise; separate fee per facade and per sign type $100
electrical_permit_fees: Fort Wayne electrical permit fees for development are as follows: For new commercial construction and additions: $0.0125 per square foot of gross floor area, with a minimum fee of $60.00. For commercial remodels, alterations, tenant finish, or renovations: Contract or estimate cost of $20,000.00 or less: $40.00; For each additional $1,000.00 or fraction thereof: an additional $4.00. Additional electrical permit fees: Temporary Service: $40.00; Electrical to in-ground swimming pool: $60.00; Re-inspection fee: $40.00.
plumbing_permit_fees: The plumbing permit fees in Fort Wayne (Allen County) are as follows: Plumbing Permit: $30.00; Each trap, vented fixture, fixture appliance or device to be installed: $20.00; Sanitary Sewer Tap: $100.00; Review Fee: 0-20 Fixtures: $40.00; Review Fee: 21-40 Fixtures: $125.00; Review Fee: 41 – plus Fixtures: $250.00.
mechanical_permit_fees: The mechanical permit fees for Fort Wayne, effective January 1, 2025, are as follows: Residential Mechanical Permit: $75.00 per unit (e.g., furnace, AC, gas line) plus a $1.00 State Surcharge Fee. An additional $10.00 gas fitting/connection fee applies for each unit over three units. Commercial Mechanical Permit and Plan Review: Fees are based on the valuation of the project.
fire_sprinkler_fees: For fire sprinkler development in Fort Wayne, based on the Allen County 2016 Fee Schedule, a Non-Sanitary Piping Permit is required. The fees are as follows: for a contract or estimate up to $20,000.00, the fee is $40.00. For each additional $1,000.00 or fraction thereof, an additional $4.00 is charged.
elevator_permit_fees: Elevator permit fees in Fort Wayne, Indiana, are regulated by the Indiana Department of Homeland Security (DHS). The fees for regulated lifting devices are as follows: Installation or Alteration Permit: Vertical wheelchair lift, incline wheelchair lift, and incline chair lift: $250; Any other regulated lifting device (including elevator, escalator, belt manlift, personnel hoist, sewage lift station personnel hoist, or dumbwaiter): $500. Initial or Renewal Operating Certificate: $120. Temporary Operating Permit: $100. Additionally, professional licensing fees for elevator-related roles are: Elevator contractor: $500; Elevator inspector: $100; Elevator mechanic: $100; Temporary elevator mechanic: $100; Emergency elevator mechanic: $25.
tenant_improvement_fees: For development in Fort Wayne, fees related to tenant improvements are categorized under various permits and reviews. The Allen County and Fort Wayne Department of Planning Services Fee Schedule (effective March 1, 2025) indicates: Site Plan Review (Non-Residential or Multiple Family Dwelling): Projects less than 1,000 square feet: $250; Projects of 1,000 square feet to 10,000 square feet: $500; Projects of over 10,000 square feet: $1,000. Downtown Pre-Review: Minor Facade Renovation: $50; Major Facade Renovation: $350.
subdivision_fees: PP/SP: Major Plat Primary or Secondary Major Plat - No Per Lot Fee $1,000 Single Lot Primary or Secondary Plat Amendment $250. PMP/SMP: Minor Plat Primary or Secondary Minor Plat $500. VALY/VROW/VEAS: Vacation Petition for Vacation (Plat, Right of Way, or Easement) $500.
platting_fees: PP/SP: Major Plat Primary or Secondary Major Plat - No Per Lot Fee $1,000 Single Lot Primary or Secondary Plat Amendment $250. PMP/SMP: Minor Plat Primary or Secondary Minor Plat $500.
annexation_fees: Fort Wayne charges a $1,000 deposit for processing voluntary annexations, which is refundable 15 days after the adoption of an annexation ordinance, unless withdrawn. This fee may be waived by the Planning Department under certain circumstances. For development, a system development charge (SDC) is assessed for permanent connections to the Fort Wayne water system. Additionally, an initial application fee of $200 is required for the use of rights-of-way.
development_agreement_fees: N/A - The Fort Wayne and Allen County Department of Planning Services Fee Schedule, effective March 1, 2025, includes the following fees related to development: Development Plan (Primary or Secondary Development Plan or Master Sign Plan): $1,000; Major Plat Primary or Secondary Major Plat - No Per Lot Fee: $1,000; Roadway Easement Agreement: $150. For Economic Redevelopment Area (ERA) Designation and Economic Development Commission (EDC) Bonds, the fee information requires contacting staff.
public_improvement_fees: Fort Wayne's public improvement fees related to development include 'City Development Fees' for water improvements, which encompass Stormwater/SWPPP Review Fees, SWPPP Inspection Fees, and a Construction Inspection & Testing Fee. Additionally, there are specific 'Water Service Availability Fees' for certain development areas such as the Wheelock Road Corridor Area ($545.00 per water service connection), Till Road Area ($123.00 per water service connection), and Thomas Road/Bass Road Area ($123.00 per water service connection).
bond_processing_fees: The bond processing fee for Economic Development Bonds in Fort Wayne is 50 cents for every $1,000 or portion thereof of the total bond issue amount. One-half of this fee is due at the time of application, and the remainder is due at closing. This fee is non-refundable.
application_fees: Fort Wayne development application fees, effective March 1, 2025, include: PERMITS: Accessory Structure (200 sq ft or less): $50; Attached Building/Structure (200 sq ft or less): $50; Building/Structure (over 200 sq ft): $100; New Single Family Residence: $150; New Duplex: $150; New Group Residential Facility (Small): $150; New Integrated Accessory Dwelling Unit: $150; New Freestanding Accessory Dwelling Unit: $150; Fence (All Zoning Districts): $30; Signs (On-premise or Off-premise): $100 (per facade and sign type); Swimming Pools (Residential): $100; Swimming Pools (Non-Residential): $500. BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS: Development Standards Variance (A1, A3, AR, R1, R2, R3, RP Districts): $350; Development Standards Variance (All Other Zoning Districts): $500; Use Variance (All Requests): $500; Special Use (All Requests): $500; Contingent Use (All Requests): $500. ADMINISTRATION FEES: Zoning verification general (zoning only): $2; Zoning verification research (zoning, adjacent zoning, violations, overlay, BZA history): $100; Administrative Property Split (Incorporated Areas Only): $150; Roadway Easement Agreement: $150.
hearing_fees: The Fort Wayne Department of Planning Services Fee Schedule (effective March 1, 2025) lists the following hearing-related fees for development: PLAN COMMISSION - Continued FEE: PDP: Development Plan (Primary or Secondary Development Plan or Master Sign Plan): $1,000; REZ: Rezoning requests: $1,000; REZ: Downzoning an existing SFR use to R1 Zoning: $250; PP/SP: Major Plat Primary or Secondary Major Plat - No Per Lot Fee: $1,000; PMP/SMP: Minor Plat Primary or Secondary Minor Plat: $500; VALY/VROW/VEAS: Vacation Petition for Vacation (Plat, Right of Way, or Easement): $500. BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS FEE: DSV: Development Standards Variance (A1, A3, AR, R1, R2, R3, RP Districts): $350; DSV: Development Standards Variance (All Other Zoning Districts): $500; UVAR: Use Variance - All Requests: $500; SU: Special Use - All Requests: $500; CU: Contingent Use - All Requests: $500; Renewal or modification of conditions of Hearing Officer or Board of Zoning Appeals approvals: $350 $400; Appeal of Hearing Officer decision to the Board of Zoning Appeals: $400; Petition to appeal a Zoning Administrator determination, interpretation or decision: $400.
appeal_fees: The appeal fees in Fort Wayne, effective March 1, 2025, are: Appeal of Hearing Officer decision to the Board of Zoning Appeals: $400; Petition to appeal a Zoning Administrator determination, interpretation or decision: $400. Additionally, other Board of Zoning Appeals fees include: Development Standards Variance (A1, A3, AR, R1, R2, R3, RP Districts): $350; Development Standards Variance (All Other Zoning Districts): $500; Use Variance - All Requests: $500; Special Use - All Requests: $500; Contingent Use - All Requests: $500.
modification_fees: Fort Wayne development modification fees include: Development Plan: Primary or Secondary Development Plan or Master Sign Plan: $1,000. Rezoning: Rezoning requests: $1,000; Downzoning an existing SFR use to R1 Zoning: $250. Plat: Primary or Secondary Major Plat - No Per Lot Fee: $1,000; Single Lot Primary or Secondary Plat Amendment: $250; Primary or Secondary Minor Plat: $500. Vacation Petition: For Vacation (Plat, Right of Way, or Easement): $500. Downtown Pre-Review: Minor Facade Renovation: $50; Major Facade Renovation: $350; New Construction/Addition: $350. Other: Written Commitment Amendment: $500; Amendment to Restrictive Covenants: $100; Correction of Scrivener's Error: $100. Board of Zoning Appeals Fees (Development Standards Variance): A1, A3, AR, R1, R2, R3, RP Districts (one fee - unlimited number of requests): $350; All Other Zoning Districts (one fee - unlimited number of requests): $500. These fees are effective March 1, 2025.
extension_fees: The filing fee for a Fort Wayne Secondary Development Plan is $600, payable to the Allen County Treasurer.
reinspection_fees: The city of Fort Wayne is proposing a reinspection fee of $175 when inspectors are required to return to a site for an inspection.
after_hours_fees: Fort Wayne has various after-hours fees, including a $240 service call fee for Fort Wayne City Utilities when service is required after business hours. Additionally, the city's comprehensive fee, fine, and penalty ordinance (§ 41.07) outlines fees for establishments operating after certain hours, such as $1,000 before 1:00 a.m. and an additional $500 for each hour of operation after 1:00 a.m.
duplicate_permit_fees: N/A - There is no specific information available regarding 'duplicate permit fees' or their development in Fort Wayne, based on the publicly available fee schedules and general web search results.
coastal_commission_fees: N/A - Fort Wayne, Indiana, does not appear to have a coastal commission or any associated fees for coastal development, as it is an inland city.
airport_overlay_fees: N/A - There is no specific fee explicitly identified as 'Fort Wayne airport overlay fees development' within the Fort Wayne-Allen County Airport Authority's 2022 Rates and Charges Ordinance. However, 'Non-refundable Filing Fees' are associated with 'Special Use Airport Overlay District Applications.' The Airport Authority also charges various fees related to terminal building space rental and air cargo apron use, which may apply to development within the airport.
flood_zone_fees: The fees for a Floodplain Development Permit in Fort Wayne, effective March 1, 2025, are: In an agricultural or residential zoning district, not part of another permit or process: $100; In commercial or industrial zoning district, not part of another permit or process: $200; In any zoning district, as part of another permit or process: $0; Zoning Ordinance "Exceptions to Compensation Requirements", not part of another permit or process: $100; Finished project grade changes in the floodplain and not qualifying for the Zoning Ordinance "Exceptions to Compensation Requirements", not part of another permit or process: $300.
seismic_review_fees: N/A - The Fort Wayne Department of Planning Services fee schedule, effective March 1, 2025, does not explicitly list 'seismic review fees' for development.
wildfire_prevention_fees: N/A - Fort Wayne does not appear to have specific 'wildfire prevention fees development' as a distinct category within its fire codes or fee structures. The city's fire prevention code establishes various fees related to general fire prevention, inspections, and permits for activities such as open burning (which requires a permit from the Fire Department, though recreational campfires typically do not), storage of tires, temporary propane tanks, and registration for fire and life safety protection service contractors. Additionally, Fort Wayne City Utilities lists 'Public Fire Protection' rates. However, no direct information regarding fees specifically for 'wildfire prevention development' or development within a wildland urban interface was found in the official city code or fire department resources.
desert_conservation_fees: N/A - I could not find any specific "desert conservation fees" or "conservation fees" for development in Fort Wayne. The search results indicate general "City Development Fees" related to water contracts, and environmental considerations for development, such as EPA funding for projects like the North River site.
school_district_fees_specific: N/A - Fort Wayne school districts do not directly charge development or impact fees. The state of Indiana provides funding to school corporations to cover related costs.
water_district_fees_specific: Fort Wayne City Utilities implements 'Monthly Capital Improvement Surcharges' (capital charges) to cover the cost of capital improvements made in areas anticipating future development. These charges serve to reimburse City Utilities or developers for their investments, ensuring that 'growth pays for growth.' The charges are added to customers' monthly bills, typically ranging from $20-25/month. The duration of these surcharges is estimated based on the cost of infrastructure and the projected number of benefiting customers, with active areas like Rothman (18 years), Tiernan Shed B (19 years), Neuhaus (21 years), and Upper Ely (30 years) having projected lengths of time for the surcharge.
fire_district_fees_specific: Fort Wayne fire district fees for development are categorized under Public Fire Protection, Private Fire Protection, and Private Fire Hydrant Rental, with rates varying based on the size of the connection (for public and private protection) and per hydrant for private rental. For Public Fire Protection, monthly charges range from $3.30 for a 5/8″ connection to $1,211.57 for a 12″ connection inside the city. Private Fire Protection ranges from $0.38 for a 1″ connection to $552.95 for a 16″ connection inside the city. Private Fire Hydrant Rental is $41.92 per hydrant per month inside the city.
improvement_district_fees: For 2025, the City of Fort Wayne will pay the Downtown Improvement District (DID) a fixed amount of $185,000 for professional economic development services. Additionally, $65,000 will be paid to the DID for a Capital Improvements Fund to benefit the Downtown Economic Improvement District.
assessment_district_fees: In Fort Wayne, the Downtown Improvement District assessment is 0.0015 of the real estate property value. These assessments are proportionately assessed and collected by the Allen County Auditor’s Office as part of the spring property tax bill. The District is governed by a Board of Directors comprised primarily of property owners within the 99-block district, who also ultimately determine the organization's renewal.

plan_check_fees: Current initial fees for structural permits for commercial development in Indianapolis are $478.00. However, a new proposal, expected to take effect on January 1, 2026, if approved, would significantly increase these fees: For a new 2,500-square-foot home, plan review and structural fee permits would increase from approximately $430 to over $1,000. For a new 25,000-square-foot business or multi-family apartment building, these same permits would increase from roughly $1,700 to $4,800.
permit_issuance_fees: Current permit issuance fees for development in Indianapolis can be found in the Fee Schedule (as of 8/7/2020) available on the indy.gov website. Recent news articles from August 2025 indicate proposed increases, including a plan review fee increase from $148 to $200 and a structural fee increase from $286 to $850. New fees for stop work order violations are also proposed: $750 for commercial projects and $250 for residential projects.
inspection_fees: Indianapolis is proposing to increase development inspection fees. These include new reinspection fees of $175, new stop work order violation fees of $750 for commercial projects and $250 for residential projects. Commercial inspection fees are also set to increase, with same-day inspections for commercial structures rising from $232 to $750, next-day inspections from $187 to $300, scheduled next-day inspections from $245 to $500, and weekday after-hours or weekend inspections from $348 to $750. Residential inspection costs are not proposed to change.
expedited_review_fees: Indianapolis offers two types of expedited review fees for development: 1. The Accelerated Plan Review for commercial development permits is billed at a higher hourly rate. The specific hourly rate is not publicly disclosed in the provided information. 2. The Indiana Department of Homeland Security charges a fixed fee of $5,000 for expedited submittal, in addition to other applicable fees from Categories A through H. Both the City of Indianapolis and the Indiana Department of Homeland Security may need to be submitted to simultaneously for some projects.
resubmittal_fees: N/A - Based on the available information from the Indianapolis city government's fee schedule and a proposed ordinance detailing fee changes for development and permits, there is no explicit mention or schedule for 'resubmittal fees' for development in Indianapolis. The documents detail initial permit fees, inspection fees, and penalties for violations, but do not use the term 'resubmittal fees'.
temporary_certificate_fees: N/A - The City of Indianapolis/Marion County does not issue 'temporary certificates' in the context of a Certificate of Occupancy. Instead, a 'Certificate of Completion and Compliance' is required. An administrative fee is assessed for the late filing of this certificate (more than 30 days after the permit's expiration), but the exact amount of this fee for 2024-2025 is not specified on the official Indianapolis government websites. For tent and temporary structure permits, the City of Indianapolis Department of Business and Neighborhood Services handles applications. While requirements are outlined for notifications and permits (depending on size and usage), specific fees for these permits in 2024-2025 are not explicitly listed on the official city websites. The Indy Parks 2025 Special Event Permit Application indicates that additional permitting through the Department of Business and Neighborhood Services may be required for larger tents and stages, with associated fees, but the amounts are not specified in the document.
demolition_permit_fees: The demolition permit fee in Indianapolis for the removal of primary Class 2 structures located on the same premises is $127.00.
water_capacity_fees: Indianapolis water capacity fees are referred to as 'System Development Charges' by Citizens Water (Citizens Energy Group). These charges are based on the size of the service pipe or meter installed when connecting to the water system. For example, a 5/8 inch connection has a System Development Charge of $1,200.00, while a 10 inch connection is $138,000.00.
sewer_capacity_fees: For Indianapolis, a new sanitary sewer connection incurs a $2,530 connection fee and a $236 permit fee. There may also be a subsequent connector fee if connecting to a sanitary sewer main that is less than 10 years old. Commercial, industrial, or multi-family connection fees are based on various factors and require a Connection Fee Calculation Worksheet.
water_transmission_fees: Indianapolis water transmission fees related to development include an Area Rate Tap Fee of $200.00, a Secondary Connector Fee of $500.00, and a Monthly Area Rate Surcharge which is determined by dividing the main extension cost by the total frontage of lots benefiting from the extension. Additionally, the Water Service Tariff outlines rules for main extensions, including how costs are determined, revenue allowances, and subsequent connector's fees for new connections to the water system.
sewer_transmission_fees: For Indianapolis, connecting a new sewer service line incurs a $2,530 connection fee and a $236 permit fee. Additionally, a 'subsequent connector fee' ranging from a few hundred to a few thousand dollars may apply if connecting to a sanitary sewer main less than 10 years old, which is a portion of the original main construction cost. For commercial, industrial, or multi-family uses, the connection fee is based on various factors calculated via a Connection Fee Calculation Worksheet. While specific development fees titled 'sewer transmission fees development' were not found, the connection and subsequent connector fees directly relate to the development of sewer transmission infrastructure. Nearby municipalities, such as Whitestown, Indiana, implement 'Regional Sewer Improvement Charges' of $1,500 per equivalent dwelling unit (EDU) for new development, and Hamilton County, Indiana, has a 'system development charge' of $5,200 per EDU for new connections.
transportation_fees: IndyGo is implementing transportation fee developments. Effective January 1, 2026, base fares will increase to $2.75. Additionally, effective July 1, 2026, IndyGo Access fares will increase, and 10-trip, 31-day, S-Passes, and Summer Youth Passes will no longer be sold.
parks_recreation_fees: N/A - The Indianapolis Board of Parks and Recreation approved the 2025 Fees and Charges and the Employee Discount Program on December 17, 2024.
public_safety_fees: Indianapolis is proposing to increase various permit and violation fees to generate up to $5 million in annual new revenue for its Department of Business and Neighborhood Services (DBNS), a self-funded agency overseeing property use, safety, and maintenance. These proposed changes, which would take effect on January 1, 2026, include more than doubling some permitting fees for building homes and businesses, increasing most zoning violation penalties from a flat $50 to between $100 and $325, and implementing new fees for building reinspections and violations of stop-work orders ($250 for homes, $750 for businesses).
fire_protection_fees: Indianapolis development projects are subject to the Indiana Department of Homeland Security's Plan Review Fee Schedule for construction design releases, which covers fire and building services. These fees include: All Projects: A minimum of $150 ($75 filing fee + $75 minimum processing fee). Categorical Processing Fees: Category A (Normal Occupancy): $0.050 per gross square foot of floor area. Category B (Minimal Occupancy – Area Related): $0.030 per gross square foot of floor area. Category C (Cost Related - Remodeling/Renovation): $0.0030 per total square footage of remodeling/renovation. Category D (Minimal Occupancy – Cost Related): $0.0002 per construction cost. Category F (Flammable Liquid or Gas Facilities): $80 per tank. Category H (Shell Building and Initial Tenant Build-Out): $0.040 per gross square foot for the shell building, and $0.020 per gross square foot for the initial tenant build-out. Category I (Expedited Plan Review): $5,000 plus the applicable fee from Categories A through H.
library_fees: The Indianapolis Public Library eliminated late fees through a new policy adopted in July 2020, which took effect at the start of 2021. This change also waived approximately $2 million in existing late fees. However, other fees for services and materials, such as those for lost or damaged items, printing, and non-resident library cards, continue to be charged.
school_impact_fees: N/A - Indianapolis does not currently have school impact fees for new residential development. While legislation was introduced in 2009 (House Bill 1400) to authorize school corporations to adopt such fees, recent reports indicate that Indianapolis has not implemented them, unlike some surrounding cities such as Fishers and Noblesville.
general_government_fees: Indianapolis is proposing increases for general government fees related to development, including permit fees, inspections, and penalties for code and ordinance violations. These changes are based on a review by Baker Tilly and aim to cover actual costs, bringing in an estimated $5 million more annually for the Department of Business and Neighborhood Services (DBNS). Some fees haven't been updated since 1988. Key proposed changes include: Residential Development Fees: Plan review for a 2,500 sq ft new residential build would increase from $148 to $200, and the structural fee from $286 to $850. Commercial Development Fees: For a 25,000 sq ft new commercial build, a new $200 plan review fee is proposed, and the structural fee would increase from $1,726 to $4,600. Violation Penalties: Many first-offense penalties, previously a flat $50, would increase to $100, $250, or $325, depending on the violation (e.g., sign violation to $100, work without improvement location to $250, commercial vehicle parking to $325). Illegal dumping of hazardous waste would increase from $500 to $1,000. Inspection Fees: New fees include a $175 reinspection fee, a $750 fee for a stop work order violation in commercial projects, and a $250 fee for stop work order violations in residential projects. Same-day commercial inspections would increase from $232 to $750, and next-day inspections would also see increases. Residential inspection costs would not change. These changes require approval from both the City-County Council and the Board of Business and Neighborhood Services.
storm_drainage_fees: The Indianapolis storm drainage fee for 2025 is $1.60 per Base Billing Unit (BBU). The fee is calculated by measuring the impervious area (IA) for each parcel and assigning BBUs proportionally to each one thousand-square foot increment of IA.
water_meter_fees: Indianapolis water meter fees related to development include a System Development Charge and a fee for establishing an account and installing a meter. The System Development Charge varies by connection size: 5/8 inch ($1,200.00), 3/4 inch ($1,800.00), 1 inch ($3,000.00), 1 1/2 inch ($6,000.00), 2 inch ($9,600.00), 3 inch ($18,000.00), 4 inch ($30,000.00), 6 inch ($60,000.00), 8 inch ($96,000.00), and 10 inch ($138,000.00). Fees for establishing an account and installing a meter are: 5/8 or 3/4 inch ($19.00), 1 inch ($68.00), 1 1/2 inch ($81.00), 2 inch ($95.00), 3 inch ($160.00), 4 inch ($200.00), and 6 inch ($337.00).
sewer_connection_fees: In Indianapolis, the sewer connection fees for development include a $236.00 permit fee and a $2,530 connection fee.
water_service_line_fees: For new water service line connections in Indianapolis, Citizens Energy Group assesses a System Development Charge and a New Meter Install Charge. Additionally, if a water main is less than 10 years old, a subsequent connector fee may be applied. These charges appear on the customer's first water bill.
fire_service_connection_fees: In Indianapolis, private fire services are not subject to connection fees and system development charges. The developer is responsible for the complete installation of the fire service. There are, however, monthly charges for private fire services based on the diameter of the service line, ranging from $3.20 for a 2-inch diameter to $355.08 for a 12-inch diameter.
reclaimed_water_fees: N/A - There is no readily available information on "Indianapolis reclaimed water fees development." The search results indicate general information about water reuse in Indiana and car wash reclaim systems in Indianapolis, but no specific programs or fee structures related to reclaimed water development in the city.
utility_relocation_fees: The Indianapolis Department of Public Works coordinates with utility companies to limit utility relocation costs for development projects. While no specific fee schedule for Indianapolis utility relocation was found, utility companies may recover relocation costs through fees passed on to their customers. A relevant Indiana Supreme Court ruling in a case involving the City of Carmel (though not Indianapolis directly) indicated that municipalities cannot unfairly impose utility relocation costs on utility companies if it leads to increased customer rates.
grading_permit_fees: N/A - The specific grading permit fees for development in Indianapolis could not be determined from the available online government resources. While grading permits are required for certain land alterations and are handled by the Department of Business and Neighborhood Services, the detailed fee schedule was provided in an unreadable Excel format. Other relevant pages on the Indianapolis government website did not list specific grading permit fees.
drainage_fees_site: Indianapolis drainage fees are calculated based on the impervious area (IA) of each parcel. As of 2025, the monthly fee is $1.60 per Base Billing Unit (BBU). One BBU is assigned for 1-1,000 square feet of IA, two BBUs for 1,001-2,000 square feet, and so on, with an additional BBU for every subsequent 1,000 square feet of IA. These fees are typically included on property tax bills or directly invoiced to tax-exempt parcels. For site development in Indianapolis, specifically for commercial (Class 1) projects, various permits and associated fees are required: Initial Structural Permit Fees: $478.00. Infrastructure Review: This process often begins the permitting for commercial construction and, if applicable, a drainage permit. Improvement Location Permit: Requires submission of a landscape plan (if applicable), detailed site plan, legal description, and building elevations, and a lighting plan. Structural Permit: Requires a pre-permit plan review for Class 1 structures and the payment of initial fees. Pre-permit Plan Review: Required for all Class 1 structures (commercial, industrial, and multi-family) and covers construction, accessibility, land use, and life safety. An accelerated plan review is available at a higher hourly rate. Other Permits: Additional permits may be required for sewer connection, flood, drainage, wrecking, and improvement location before a structural permit is released. Electrical Permit: Required for most electrical power distribution system construction. Heating and Cooling Permit: Required for heating, venting, air conditioning, or refrigeration system construction. Wrecking Permit: Required for demolition activities.
private_street_fees: N/A - Indianapolis does not have a specific fee explicitly named "private street fees development." However, development involving private streets in Indianapolis is subject to several applicable fees and requirements: 1. Stormwater User Fees: Private roadways are considered impervious surfaces and are subject to stormwater user fees. These fees are calculated based on the impervious area of the parcel, with a rate of $1.60 per Base Billing Unit (BBU) in 2025. 2. Permits and Inspection Fees: The construction of private streets would fall under various permits and inspections managed by the Department of Business and Neighborhood Services. Relevant fees could include: Right-of-way permits: $50.00, Road and street construction permits: $100.00, Site plan review fees: $100.00, Inspections: $50.00. 3. Subdivision Fees: If the private street development is part of a larger land subdivision, additional fees apply, including: Filing fee (preliminary plat): $100.00, Inspection fee (per inspection): $50.00, Review fee (final plat): $100.00. Additionally, developers are responsible for the actual construction costs of private streets, which must adhere to the thoroughfare plan as part of subdivision improvements.
landscaping_review_fees: The Metropolitan Development Commission of Indianapolis has a fee schedule (effective January 1, 2011) that includes various fees related to development. While a specific 'landscaping review fee' is not explicitly itemized, charges apply for petitioning changes in land use, site development standards, and modifications to site plans. Some relevant fees include: Filing Fees for Zoning Base Map Changes (Rezoning): Commercial or Industrial District: $2,789.00 plus $19.00 per acre over 1 acre. Special District (includes Special Use, University Quarter, Hospital, Historic Preservation, Speedway, and Park Districts): $2,789.00 plus $19.00 per acre over 1 acre. D-P District (Planned Unit Development) or C-S District (Special Commercial District): $3,499.00 plus $19.00 per acre over 1 acre. Dwelling District over three acres: $2,789.00 plus $19.00 per acre over 1 acre. Dwelling District three acres or less: $479.00. Petition for Variance or Special Exception: Variance of Development Standards: Dwelling Districts Zoning Ordinance: $550.00 plus $29.00 for each variance of development standards requested. Commercial, Industrial and All Other Zoning Ordinances: $1,970.00 plus $29.00 for each variance of development standards requested. Petition to Modify a Previously-approved Petition: Approval to modify or terminate a site plan, elevation or other plan in D-P, C-S, or Special District: $2,199.00. Approval to modify or terminate a site plan, elevation or other plan in all other districts: $2,099.00. For one single- or two-family dwelling, to modify or terminate a site plan, elevation or other plan: $529.00. These fees are from a schedule effective January 1, 2011, and may have been updated since then.
irrigation_permit_fees: N/A - For specific information regarding irrigation permit fees in Indianapolis, it is recommended to contact the Indianapolis Department of Business and Neighborhood Services (DBNS) directly at 317.327.8700 or email permitquestions@indy.gov. While there isn't a dedicated 'irrigation permit fee' listed online, such installations typically fall under plumbing or general construction permits.
pool_spa_permit_fees: Indianapolis residential pool and spa development requires a new swimming pool construction permit from the Marion County Public Health Department, which costs $100. If the permit is not obtained before construction, the fee increases to $300. Additionally, residential pools and hot tubs require structural, improvement location, and drainage permits from the City of Indianapolis. Recent proposed fee increases in Indianapolis indicate a structural permit fee of $850 (up from $286) and a plan review fee of $200 (up from $148). Specific fees for residential improvement location and drainage permits for pools/spas in Indianapolis were not explicitly found in the provided search results.
fence_permit_fees: N/A - The official fee schedule for licenses and permits in Indianapolis can be found on the City of Indianapolis website. The fee schedule, as of 8/7/2020, is available as an Excel file.
zoning_review_fees: Indianapolis is proposing to increase zoning review fees related to development. For a 2,500-square-foot new residential build, the plan review fee would increase from $148 to $200, and the structural fee would increase from $286 to $850. For a 25,000-square-foot new commercial build, the plan review fee, previously included in the structural fee, is now proposed at $200, and the structural fee would increase from $1,726 to $4,600.
conditional_use_fees: For Indianapolis development, conditional use fees may fall under 'Petition requesting a Zoning Base Map Change (Rezoning) to a Special District' which costs $2,789.00 plus $19.00 for each acre or any portion thereof over 1 acre. Alternatively, 'Special Exceptions pertaining to Commercial or Industrial Use' are $1,650.00 plus $29.00 for each variance of development standards requested. Fees for 'Master Plan or Use Approval (excluding signs)' in a Special District are $2,789.00. These fees are effective as of January 1, 2011.
variance_fees: The variance fees for development standards in Indianapolis, effective January 1, 2011, are as follows: Dwelling Districts Zoning Ordinance: $550.00 plus $29.00 for each variance of development standards requested. Sign Regulations for on-premise sign(s): $1,970.00 plus $29.00 for each variance of development standards requested. Sign Regulations for off-premise sign(s): $3,270.00 plus $29.00 for each variance of development standards requested. Commercial, Industrial and All Other Zoning Ordinances: $1,970.00 plus $29.00 for each variance of development standards requested.
rezoning_fees: The Indianapolis rezoning and development fees, as of January 1, 2011, are as follows: Zoning Base Map Change (Rezoning): Commercial or Industrial District: $2,789.00 plus $19.00 for each acre or any portion thereof over 1 acre. Special District (Special Use, University Quarter, Hospital, Historic Preservation, Speedway, Park Districts): $2,789.00 plus $19.00 for each acre or any portion thereof over 1 acre. D-P District (Planned Unit Development) or C-S District (Special Commercial District): $3,499.00 plus $19.00 for each acre or any portion thereof over 1 acre. Dwelling District over three acres: $2,789.00 plus $19.00 for each acre or any portion thereof over 1 acre. Dwelling District three acres or less: $479.00. Gravel-Sand-Borrow District (GsB), Special Use District XIII (SU-13), Special Use District XXIII (SU-23), Special Use District XXVIII (SU-28), or Special Use District XLI (SU-41): $5,499.00 plus $69.00 for each acre or any portion thereof over 1 acre. Any other District: $3,299.00 plus $19.00 for each acre or any portion thereof over 1 acre. Development-related Approvals (Commission Approval): Regional Center (RC) Approvals: RC New Construction, Addition to, or Exterior Renovation of a Building or Parking Garage (excluding single- and two-family residential): Less than 5,000 square feet and less than 2 stories and not a High Impact Project: $479.00; High Impact Project - 5,000 to 30,000 square feet or between 3 stories and 6 stories: $1,299.00; High Impact Project - Over 30,000 square feet or 7 stories or more: $1,999.00. RC Surface Parking Lot: $2,299.00. RC Wireless Facility: $450.00. RC Sidewalk Cafe: $450.00. RC Non-building structures only, such as art, appurtenances, etc.: $450.00. RC Building Identification Signs (petitions for multiple Building Identification signs are levied the largest applicable base fee and then the per sign fee): Window signs: No cost; Wall, Awning, Canopy, Projecting, Marquee, or Suspended sign 64 square feet or less: $450.00 plus $29.00 per sign.; Wall, Awning, Canopy, Projecting, Marquee, or Suspended sign greater than 64 square feet: $1,250.00 plus $29.00 per sign.; Roof Signs: $2,270.00 plus $29.00 per sign.; All Other Building Identification signs: $450.00 plus $29.00 per sign. RC Freestanding Sign: $1,870.00 per sign. RC Off-Premises Sign: $3,299.00 per sign face. RC Construction, addition to, or renovation of an individual Single or Two-family dwelling, addition, Outbuilding, or associated accessory structure: No cost. RC Paint Color: No cost. RC Demolition not considered a High Impact Project: $479.00. RC Demolition considered a High Impact Project: $1,999.00. Approvals in a Special District (e.g. Hospital, University Quarter, Park, Speedway) for: New Construction, Addition to, or Exterior Renovation of a Building or Parking Garage (excluding single-and two-family residential): $2,789.00. Surface Parking lot: $2,789.00. On-premise Signs: $2,760.00 plus $29.00 per sign. Off-Premises Sign: $3,299.00 per sign. Construction, addition to, or renovation of an individual Single or Two-family dwelling, addition, outbuilding, or associated accessory structure: $479.00. Single or Two-family residential Subdivision: $2,789.00. Master Plan or Use Approval (excluding signs): $2,789.00. Other Fees (Modifications, Variances, Plats, Vacations, Administrative Appeals, Miscellaneous): Consult the full Fee Schedule document for these details.
planned_development_fees: N/A - Indianapolis does not have planned development fees in the form of impact fees. However, the city does have various permit fees for building and development, as well as zoning violation penalties, which are subject to change.
design_review_fees: The design review fees for development in Indianapolis, as outlined by the Indiana Department of Homeland Security, consist of a Filing Fee of $75 plus a Processing Fee with a minimum of $75, totaling a minimum of $150. The processing fee varies based on the project category: Category A (Normal Occupancy): $0.050 times the gross square feet of floor area. Category B (Minimal Occupancy – Area Related): $0.030 times the gross square feet of floor area. Category C (Cost Related - Remodeling and Renovation): $0.0030 times the total square footage of the remodeling and renovation. Category D (Minimal Occupancy – Cost Related): $0.0002 times the construction cost. Category E (Swimming Pools): $0.020 times the gross cubic feet. Category F (Flammable Liquid or Gas Facilities): $80 for each tank (initial installation or replacement). Category G (Replicated Floor Plan Buildings): $0.040 times the gross square foot for one example of each replicated plan, plus $69 per building. Category H (Shell Building and Initial Tenant Build-Out): $0.040 times the gross square feet for the shell, and $0.020 times the gross square feet for the initial tenant build-out. Category I (Expedited Plan Review): $5,000, plus the applicable fee from Categories A through H. This service provides a design release by 4:30 PM the next business day if submitted by 9:00 AM. Additional special processing fees include: Additional submission for a partially filed project: $250. Surcharge for late filing: $300. Foundation release: $80. Addenda and revisions (each system modified per submission): $35. Master Plans (each series or structure): $173. Incomplete project filing (mailed submissions only): $12. Returned checks: $35. Reinstatement or time extension of design release: $50.
historic_review_fees: Indianapolis Historic Preservation Commission (IHPC) Certificates of Appropriateness (COA) application fees for development are as follows: Items Requiring No Fee: Plant materials, lighting, painting, fencing, temporary ramps, mailboxes, small vents, and mechanical equipment (excluding cell equipment and solar panels). Renovation/Site Improvements: Fees are based on the project cost: $0-$1,000: $0 (or $100 for late application); $1,001-$5,000: $50; $5,001-$10,000: $100; $10,001-$15,000: $150; >$15,000: $10 per $1,000. New Construction/Move Buildings: $500, plus $0.70 per square foot. Demolition: Primary Structures (Historic): $5,000; Primary Structures (Non-Historic): $500; Accessory Structures/Additions (Historic): $600; Accessory Structures/Additions (Non-Historic): $100. Signs: Fees vary by type and size. Land Use Changes in an HP-1 Zoning District-Lockerbie Square (not requiring a variance): $500. Land Use COA's (Variance/Rezoning, etc): $50. Zoning and Variance Petitions: Fees are the same as Current Planning (details on www.indy.gov/cp). Preliminary Review: $600 ($500 is credited towards the full application fee). Amendment to COA: $600. Extension of COA Deadline: Half of the original filing fee. Appeal of Hearing Officer Decision: $100. Late application fees are generally three times the timely fee.
environmental_review_fees: An environmental assessment in Indiana costs, on average, between $1,750.00 and $3,000. The price can vary based on factors such as the site’s location, historical complexity, and whether any additional research is needed.
tree_removal_fees: In Indianapolis, a 'flora permit' is required for any tree removal work in the city's right-of-way. There is no cost to apply for this flora permit.
wetlands_review_fees: N/A - There are currently no application fees for state-regulated wetland permits in Indiana. Additionally, Indiana no longer requires developers to obtain state wetland permits or perform compensatory mitigation for impacts to isolated wetlands.
air_quality_fees: Indianapolis air quality fees are subject to Indiana state regulations. In 2019, air permit fees increased by 27%. A 2019 law dictates that subsequent increases are limited to 10% and can only occur once every five years. There is an ongoing concern about a critical funding shortfall that may require future adjustments to Indiana's (and therefore Indianapolis's) air quality fee structure. Continuous emission monitor fees and air quality monitoring network fees are paid by January 31st annually in Indianapolis-Marion County.
noise_study_fees: A traffic noise analysis for the Emerson Avenue project in Indianapolis had a project cost (KEG Fee) of $16,400.
traffic_study_fees: N/A - Indianapolis, Indiana does not appear to have specific, established 'traffic study fees' for development. However, the City/County is exploring the implementation of transportation impact fees to help fund future transportation infrastructure needs. General permit fees are applicable to development in Indianapolis.
archaeological_fees: N/A - Based on the available information, there are no explicitly stated 'archaeological fees' for development in Indianapolis within the Indianapolis Historic Preservation Commission's Certificate of Appropriateness (COA) fee schedule. However, 'Mitigation Fees' may be applied to COA applications for work already performed that is usually nonreversible, the amount of which is determined by the Commission. It is not explicitly stated if these mitigation fees are related to archaeological considerations.
biological_survey_fees: N/A - There is no universally published fee schedule for biological surveys related to development in Indianapolis. The cost of biological surveys in Indianapolis for development projects is highly variable and depends on factors such as the scope of the survey, the specific species involved (especially endangered or threatened species like the Indiana Bat and Northern Long-Eared Bat), and the consulting firm conducting the assessment. However, some related fee structures and cost indicators were found: Data Requests: The Indiana Department of Natural Resources (DNR) Nature Preserves assesses a fee of $42 per half-hour for requests made to the Indiana Natural Heritage Data Center for information that may be relevant to biological assessments. General Biological Assessment Cost Structure (example from Navajo Nation): A cost estimate sheet for biological assessments indicated an hourly rate of $80 for research, planning, travel, review of findings, and report writing. Additional overhead costs included per diem ($50/night), mileage ($0.30/mile), a daily vehicle rate ($15/day), and a 10% administration fee. In-Lieu Fee Programs: The Range-Wide Indiana Bat and Northern Long-Eared Bat In-Lieu Fee Program exists to compensate for unavoidable impacts to these species and their habitats from development actions, suggesting that costs are associated with such projects, although specific survey fees were not detailed. Workshops: A 2-Day Intro to Sedges Workshop by Midwest Biological Survey had a cost of $450 per participant ($350 for early registration), which is an educational cost, not a development survey fee. For specific project-related biological survey fees in Indianapolis, it would be necessary to consult with environmental consulting firms specializing in biological assessments in the region.
right_of_way_fees: The Indianapolis City Council's Metropolitan and Economic Development Committee discussed proposed fee adjustments for right-of-way and drainage fees on August 18, 2025. These adjustments are part of a larger overhaul of city services and regulatory processes, as many fees have not been updated since 1988. The proposed changes aim to align fees with the actual costs of service and with those of peer jurisdictions. The fee adjustments are categorized into three groups: zoning violations, right-of-way and drainage fees, and a hybrid group. Not all fees will increase.
street_cut_fees: N/A - Indianapolis is proposing to significantly increase various permitting fees for building homes and businesses, and penalties for zoning violations, effective January 1, 2026, if approved. For example, plan review and structural fee permits for a new 2,500-square-foot home would more than double from approximately $430 to over $1,000. For a 25,000-square-foot business or multi-family apartment building, these fees would nearly triple, increasing from about $1,700 to $4,800. Most zoning violation fees would rise from a flat $50 to between $100 and $325. New penalties include a $250 fee for violating a stop-work order on a home and $750 for a business.
traffic_signal_fees: In Indianapolis, the cost of a traffic signal without turn lanes or sidewalks is approximately $75,000 to $150,000. Additionally, Indianapolis has approved a $700,000 upgrade for a traffic signal monitoring system (Centrax system) for an initial two-year term, which includes software licensing and hardware.
street_lighting_fees: For new street lighting development in Indianapolis, if the estimated 60-month revenue from the lighting does not exceed the cost of installation, the customer must pay 2.5 times the difference between the installation cost and the 60-month revenue prior to installation. Additionally, there are annual flat rates for various types of Company-owned street lighting equipment and additional facilities (e.g., poles, columns) which contribute to ongoing fees.
sidewalk_fees: In Indianapolis, the estimated cost for installing 700 linear feet of sidewalk is approximately $61,117.50. The responsibility for sidewalk installation at the time of platting falls on the developer. There are also provisions for a 'fee in lieu of sidewalk construction', where developers may pay into a sidewalk fund instead of installing sidewalks, such as a $17 per square foot fee mentioned in a related ordinance (Bargersville, but indicative of the region).
driveway_approach_fees: In Indianapolis, driveway approach fees are associated with permits required for development. The Indiana Department of Transportation (INDOT) charges $600 for Major Commercial Driveway & Major Public Road Approach permits and $150 for Minor and Sub-Minor Commercial Driveways & Minor Public Road Approach permits. Additionally, an Indianapolis right-of-way permit, which may be related to driveway approach development, has a standard application fee of $55.
oversized_load_fees: The Indiana Department of Transportation (INDOT) increased the fee for overweight divisible load permits from $0.07 per equivalent single axle load (ESAL) mile to $0.25 per ESAL mile, effective January 1, 2022. This new fee applies to any ESALs in excess of 2.4. Additionally, HEA1190-2021 allowed all commodities access to the overweight permitting system and instituted an annual limit of 8,500 single trip permits per year.
sign_permit_fees: Indianapolis sign permit fees are as follows: Advertising Signs: Application fee: $32, Permit fee for signs 0-100 square feet: $417, Permit fee for signs 101 or more square feet: $838. Business Signs (Pole, pylon, roof, ground): Application fee: $32, Permit fee: $422. Business Signs (Wall, incidental, others): Application fee: $32, Permit fee: $142. Business Signs (Awnings or canopies with signs): Application fee: $32, Permit fee: $170.
electrical_permit_fees: N/A - A precise and comprehensive fee schedule for Indianapolis electrical permits for development was not readily available through direct online searches. The official Indianapolis government website linked to a fee schedule in an XLSX format, which could not be accessed. While some information regarding general permit processes and initial structural permit fees ($478.00) was found, a specific, consolidated list of electrical permit fees for development projects in Indianapolis Marion County was not publicly accessible in an easily readable format.
plumbing_permit_fees: Current plumbing permit fees in Indianapolis (as of August 12, 2025) include an application fee of $32 and a fee of $185 for new residential plumbing installation. There is a proposal to increase general building permit fees in Indianapolis, which may indirectly affect plumbing development costs. These proposed increases, which are expected to be voted on by the DBNS board on August 28, 2025, and by the City-County Council on September 23, 2025, would take effect on January 1, 2026, if approved.
mechanical_permit_fees: N/A - The current mechanical permit fees for Indianapolis are not explicitly detailed on the Department of Business and Neighborhood Services website. The provided fee schedule is from 2020 and does not break down mechanical permit fees. It is recommended to contact the Department of Business and Neighborhood Services directly for the most up-to-date and specific fee information. Contact Information: Phone: 317.327.8700 Email: permitquestions@indy.gov
fire_sprinkler_fees: The development fees for fire sprinklers in Indianapolis are governed by the Indiana Administrative Code 675 IAC 12-3-2. The design release fees include a $75 filing fee and a processing fee of $75 minimum, resulting in a total minimum fee of $150. Additionally, for addenda and revisions to a fire extinguishing system or fire sprinkler submittal, there is a fee of $35 per system modified per submission (other than compliance corrections).
elevator_permit_fees: For regulated lifting devices, including elevators, in Indiana (which includes Indianapolis), the permit fees are as follows: - An application for an installation or alteration permit for vertical wheelchair lift, incline wheelchair lift, and incline chair lift costs $250. - An application for an installation or alteration permit for any other regulated lifting device, including elevators, escalators, belt manlifts, personnel hoists, sewage lift station personnel hoists, or dumbwaiters, costs $500. - An application for an initial or renewal operating certificate for a regulated lifting device costs $120. - An application for a temporary operating permit for a regulated lifting device costs $100.
tenant_improvement_fees: N/A - To determine specific tenant improvement fees in Indianapolis, refer to the official 'Fee Schedule (as of 8/7/2020)' provided by the Department of Business and Neighborhood Services on the indy.gov website.
subdivision_fees: The Indianapolis Metropolitan Development Commission's Fee Schedule (effective January 1, 2011) outlines the following subdivision development fees: Preliminary Plat for a Major subdivision: $2,999.00 plus $19 per lot; Preliminary Plat for a Minor subdivision: $2,299.00 plus $19 per lot; Preliminary Plat for a Cluster subdivision: $3,899.00 plus $19 per lot; Additional fee for a Waiver of Subdivision Control Ordinance: $479.00; Secondary Plat for a Major or Cluster subdivision: $1,699.00; Secondary Plat for a Minor subdivision: $499.00.
